characters: PRINTS BY THE MASTERS OF MODERN ART

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bells of a Gothic church are ringing down upon a come square near downtown Hartford. The crisp fall day is aliv with color, as cornflower skies burst through the autumn and golds, setting off the clean brick buildings and fres painted homes that so proudly distinguish this New Englan township. Music over OPENING CREDITS. We see a powder blue, ‘56 Chevrolet turn onto the main ro its way into town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chevrolet stops in front of a small dance school just State St. and an attractive, red-haired woman in her mid- thirties emerges from the car, wearing sunglasses and a scarf. She says hello to a mother and daughter exiting th school on her way inside, returning a moment later with a strawberry-haired girl in ballet clothes. CATHY WHITAKER, having collected her 8-year-old daughter JANICE from ball class is finally returning home from another busy day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy's car is turning onto a well-tended, residential street, full of traditional black-shuttered, white wood homes, each set back on spacious lawns against, the blaze autumn color

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns into the driveway of a large, fastidiously landscaped 2-story home, with a slate roof and flagstone walkway. DAVID WHITAKER, a typical 11-year-old boy, with- hair like his dad’s, is circling around the front of the house on his bright red Schwinn:

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Mother! Mother! Can I sleep over at Hutch's tonight? Mrs. Hutchinson gave permission.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (from the car) Not tonight, David. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CATHY(cont 'd) Your father, and I are going out and I need you to, look after your sister.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Aww, shucks.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Now move your school bag, David, so mother can park. The Whitaker's maid SYBIL, a handsome black woman in her early 30's, is just coming down the front steps to the ca

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: (hopping out) Sherry Seeger says they only' cost something like five or six dollars Please mother, please can I?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (opening her door) Oh Sybil, thank heavens!

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Well I knew you were going to the grocery -

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: David, please help Sybil unload the car.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How come Janice doesn’t gotta?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Doesn't have to. Because Janice is carrying in all her, belongings an marching straight upstairs into the bath. She steps out of the car loaded down with laundered cloth and packages.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Your father and I have an engagement so I want you both to have a nice early dinner. And help Sybil.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID/ JANICE
dialogues.text: (not exactly in sync) Yes, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sybil, did Mr. Whitaker call while I was out?

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: No, Mrs. Whitaker. Not since you've been gone.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: How do you like that guy. Big time executive and he still can't remember a single social obligation!

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: So mother can I? Please can I get them?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Janice I said we'll discuss it with your father. Now hurry on inside. David, put your bike away and help Sybil with the groceries! Where's your jacket?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Inside. Cathy turns to see her best friend ELEANOR FINE, a lean blond woman in her early 40's, just turning up her drive shiny green Imperial.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well hello, stranger! Aren't I seeing you in about three hours time? Eleanor is stepping out of her car.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You are. But I just left the caterers this instant and I had to dash over.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You have the samples?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You bet.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Ooh. Come inside.  They start into the house.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I can only stay a second.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You just caught me, actually - David! what did I tell you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm getting the last bag!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, Janice is practicing some ballet steps by a large stone fireplace. Eleanor is in the midst of showing Cathy color samples for the big company party it is their annua venture to host.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: And imagine with the table setting I showed you. The aqua trim? Is that smart?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You like?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Mmm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (starting to put things away ) Alright. So I'll call the caterers in the morning and you confirm with Dorothy on the deposit - and honey, we're in business.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Magnavox ‘57, here we come.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You betcha.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Mother, look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janice I thought I told you to go start your bath! You know your father and I -

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Just this one part, pleeease.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Alright, bunt lickety-split. Janice performs a few steps for her mother and Eleanor as David pours over the TV guide on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Oh, will you look at that?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: That's lovely darling.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: She's getting so grown up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Mother, can I stay up and watch The Californians - Please!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Janice, honey, watch the lamp!

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Ta-da! Eleanor and Cathy applaud Janice who beams in delight.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Ohh!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: That was lovely, dear. Now hurry on up and get out of those clothes or mother's going to be late. Janice turns, still beaming, and dashes up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I better run. I still have loads to do.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well I can imagine, with Mona Lauder and that little white glove of hers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't social mores the most dreadful bore? Mona's invited us at least three times last year so of course there wasn't a thing I could do. And Stan sees Fred at the club... Cathy opens the door for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor starts down the front steps of the house toward h car.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thanks for stopping by.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I'll see you at eight!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You know Frank. On the dot! Cathy waves goodbye and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janice is curled into an armchair in the soft glow of Cat vanity, watching her mother do her make-up in the mirror. Cathy is dressed for the evening in sleeveless emerald gr setting off the tangerine of her hair.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Mother?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (doing her lipstick) Uh-huh?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: When you were a little girl you looked like me, right?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So when I grow up does that mean I'll look like you?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Is that what you want darling, to look like me?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Yes. I hope I look exactly as pretty as you.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What a lovely compliment coming from my perfectly lovely daughter. She picks up her wristwatch and glances at the time.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Seven-fifteen!, Where on earth is your father? She gets up and walks over to a dresser.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Mother?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (searching for something) What is it, dear?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Can I try putting lipstick on me?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (starting out the door) Not tonight, Janice. Mother’s going to be late. Sybil!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy is starting down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: (off) Yes, Mrs. Whitaker?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Did I leave my gloves on the hall table?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off) Yes, ma’am. I see them.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You know it's nearly twenty after and Mr. Whitaker still hasn't phoned! Sybil meets Cathy at the foot of the stairs with the glov

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sybil... - I'm at my wits end. I even tried calling his office, though I knew there wouldn't be anyone - The phone RINGS. Sybil goes to the hall table to answer i

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well I certainly hope that's him now. Because if it isn't -

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Whitaker residence. (brief silence, then stiffly) Yes sir. One moment, please.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: (Lowered voice) Police department. Cathy frowns, taking the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (through receiver) Yes. Am I speaking with a Mrs. Frank Whitaker?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Of 1616 Sycamore Drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: One moment please. The OFFICER hands the phone over to FRANK WHITAKER, a dar haired, big-boned man in his early forties, who has just finished wiping his ink-stained fingers with a rag.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Cathy?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Frank! Frank, what happened? Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Everything's fine. It was a big - mix-up, the whole thing. But you gotta come get me. They won't - let me leave on my own.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, Frank. Don't worry, darling. I'll be there as quickly as I can. (she hangs up the phone)

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Is there anything I can do, Mrs. Whitaker?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: No. Thank you Sybil. Just keep an eye on the children. I'm sure I won't be long. Cathy grabs her purse and coat and rushes for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy's car pulls up in front of the lamp-lit police stat She hurries out of the car, still in her evening clothes, up the stone steps of the precinct  10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy walks over to the OFFICER at the desk

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Can I help you ma’am?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm here to meet my husband. The name's Whitaker, Frank Whitaker.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Here we go. Room 103. If you'll follow me, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy signs the report and hands it to the BAIL CLERK.

dialogues.speaker: BAIL CLERK
dialogues.text: This is your copy, ma'am, and your receipt.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you. Then the door opens and Frank walks through it.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, Frank! Cathy rushes to him and they embrace. As they leave, two of the officers are still watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy drives while Frank broods in the passenger seat. RE PROJECTED streetlights send charcoal shadows across their faces.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'll tell you one thing. If it hadn't been for that sniveling junior cop they'd have never gone through the whole charade in the first place!... / (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK(cont 'd) Stead of trying to save face. I saw the guy they were after - the ‘loiterer’. They wouldn't even listen to me! I tell you, I have half a mind to sue the pants off the whole precinct.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Or... you could simply forget the whole thing ever happened.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (takes a breath) I suppose you're right. Brief silence.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (a bit cautiously) So were there - drinks after work?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I thought they said something... Intoxication level, something-or- other - ?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Christ! I had a lousy cocktail with Bill after work, going over the portfolio! Should I be arrested for that too?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Of course not, darling.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The whole thing’s just put me ina fowl state.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I know, dear. You just try to rest. We’1l be home in no time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy stands in semi-darkness, on the phone with Eleanor. finds the police report in her purse.  12.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: He’s fine... The car’s fine. Frank says it was the bumper that got hit, but you know me. I can’t tell the difference... I’m just sorry we had to miss it... I know... She drops the papers into the waste-basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sits in bed with an open book on his lap, staring i space. The door squeaks open and he looks over.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: She was fine. Said it was a dreadful bore, what with Mona Lauder and her gossip.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (depleted) Cathy, I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (embracing him) Darling, you’ve nothing to be sorry for. It was all just a silly wretched mistake! They kiss deeply and he takes her in his arms. Cathy clos her eyes and begins caressing his shoulders and neck. But Frank stops and pulls away. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Feel so tired. He turns and lays down into bed and she caresses the side his head with her hand.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Course you do. You sleep now. She switches off the light, pulls up his blanket and slow walks to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Whitaker clan are all seated around the breakfast roo table finishing a breakfast of bacon and eggs.  13.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Pop, Hutch says if the Russian's drop a bomb on us we couldn't drop one back on them. Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well, son, I'm afraid Hutch has a point there.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Why, pop? Why couldn't we?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Drink your orange juice David.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: I already drank mine. Look father!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Attagirl!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Pop, why?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (glancing at the clock) Would you look at the time? It's already a quarter after! You kids are going to miss your bus! Sybil can you help me get their coats? Sybil helps Cathy distribute coats and lunch-boxes, and h them out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Alright, now. Say goodbye to your father.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Bye, father. (she kisses him)

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Goodbye, kitten.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Bye, pop!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Have a good day at school, son. David is first out the door.  14.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Janice, have you got your notebook?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Yes, Mother. David swings open the front door of the house. We can hea the bus approaching.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (off) The bus is here!

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: David - your lunch! Cathy takes it from Sybil and rushes after him.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: David! He swoops back in, grabs it, and is off again, followed b Janice.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Bye, mother!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Have a nice day at school, dear Cathy pecks her on the cheek and she runs out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus pulls up in front of the house as David and Janic running and Cathy waves.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Bye! The big yellow door closes behind them and the bus pulls down the street. A small truck is just pulling up to the house which reads DEAGAN GARDEN SUPPLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy is walking back' into the house as Frank emerges fr the kitchen, gathering his things for work.  15.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I thought you were going to have another piece of toast?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It's late. I should get over there.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well can I at least fix you lunch?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No, thank you, dear. I've got lunch meetings all week long. It's portfolio season! The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (calling) Sybil, if that's the milkman, his check is in the kitchen drawer!

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: (off) Yes, ma’am! Cathy helps Frank on with his overcoat

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well I'm just glad you're feeling better, dear.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thank you, darling. Frank embraces Cathy and kisses her warmly just as - BOOM a camera flash ignites them, and they turn. Standing beside Sybil in the entryway is MRS. LEACOCK , a grey-faced woman in her 60's, and a young PHOTOGRAPHER wi camera.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Pardon me, ma'am, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mrs. Whitaker. This is - Mrs. Leacock? She says she had an appointment with you this morning?  16.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh Jimminy - I completely forgot the time! Yes, of course, Mrs. Leacock, please come in.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEACOCK
dialogues.text: I do apologize, Mrs. Whitaker, but candid views are always the best.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Darling, this is Mrs. Leacock, the lady I told you about, from the Weekly Gazette.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Ah, yes. The fine lady who wants to air all our dirty secrets. (shaking her hand) How do you do, Mrs. Leacock?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEACOCK
dialogues.text: Fear not, Mr. Whitaker. We at the Gazette ascribe to only the highest of professional standards.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well I'm glad to hear it. Now if you'll all please excuse me, I have some professional standards of my own to keep up. (kissing Cathy) Goodbye, darling.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Goodbye, dear.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (nodding goodbye) Mrs. Leacock...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEACOCK
dialogues.text: Pleasure, Mr. Whitaker. Franks gives a final wave to the room and is gone.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEACOCK
dialogues.text: Your husband's a very charming man Mrs. Whitaker.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you. We're rather fond of him ourselves. Please, won't you come in and make yourselves at home.  17. Cathy escorts them into the living room and over to the c while untying her kitchen apron. Cathy dress.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: AS you can see, I'm just running a bit behind schedule today.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEACOCK
dialogues.text: That's quite alright, dear. sits down opposite her, casually smoothing her hair and

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I suppose I still can't imagine why in the world you’d want an interview with me in the first place. It couldn't possibly be very interesting for your readers.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEACOCK
dialogues.text: The readers of the Weekly Gazette, Mrs. Whitaker, are women just like yourself, with families and homes to keep up. A good society paper need not be a gossip rag. You are the proud wife of a successful sales executive, planning the parties and posing at her husband's side on the advertisements. She refers to a framed magazine advertisement on the wall showing Cathy and Frank posed in front of their TV with t heading: MR. & MRS. MAGNAVOX CHOOSE NOTHING BUT THE BEST

dialogues.speaker: THEIR HOME
dialogues.text: Suddenly,

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEACOCK
dialogues.text: To everyone here in Connecticut you are Mr. and Mrs. Magnavox.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I suppose I should be flattered. I just don't feel I'm so very different from anyone else, really. I like to shop and wear a pretty dress every now and then. But really my life is just like any other wife or mother's - I don't suppose I've ever really wanted anything - through the window, Cathy glimpses someone moving through her backyard. She stands.  18.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEACOCK
dialogues.text: What is it, dear?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I think I just saw someone walking through our yard. Cathy walks to the french doors leading to the backyard. There she sees A tall black man standing outside, hunching over somethin

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What on earth...?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEACOCK
dialogues.text: (standing, seeing) Oh my. Cathy opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEACOCK
dialogues.text: Mrs. Whitaker - Perhaps you should call the police -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Whitaker backyard is an ample, two-tiered expanse, wi flagstone walkways and fastidiously landscaped hedges, tr and flower-beds bordering the swimming-pool and lawn. Cathy takes a few cautious steps in the direction of the stranger.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Can I help you? The man looks up from a shrub of evergreens, squinting. T is RAYMOND DEAGAN, 40 years old, good-looking. He steps toward her, looking slightly irritated himself. Cathy takes an involuntary step back

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Ma'am, I'm sorry. My name's Raymond Deagan. I'm Otis Deagan's son. I've just been - taking over some of his jobs since he -  19.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You're Otis's son?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well I'm - terribly sorry for speaking to you in that manner. I didn't know who was in my yard.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: No need.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: How is your father? I knew he was in the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Yes, I - My father passed away, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: No! I had no idea! I'm so very sorry. (putting her hand on his arm) Please accept our deepest condolences. Your father was a wonderful, dedicated man.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Thank you. The phone rings from inside the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear Sybil answering it as Mrs. Leacock watches Cathy through the window - just removing her hand from Raymond' arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sybil steps out to the porch from the kitchen door

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Mrs. Whitaker? I have Greenhill Caterers,on the line!  20.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sybil! (to Raymond) I'm sorry. Would you excuse me a moment?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Of course. Cathy hurries back inside.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Mrs. Leacock, I'm terribly sorry! I'll just be a minute more!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is walking briskly down the wide passageway of his floor at Magnavox, passing secretarial pools and other employees with a smile. Triangles of morning sun bleach t wood-paneled walls of the floor's lean, modern decor He passes a sprite little secretary named Kitty.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Whitaker.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Morning Kitty. Lovely dress you're wearing.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. Frank continues on towards the outer office of the execut suite where his secretary, MARLENE, is stationed beneath large abstract wall-hanging. Standing opposite, pooling over a file is STAN FINE, Eleanor's husband, a tall, slightly greying man with a be who works right below Frank in the Hartford division.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Morning, Marlene, Stan!

dialogues.speaker: MARLENE
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Whitaker.  21.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: So how's the second best golfer in Hartford this morning?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Someone break the books already? Don't tell me our wives' party budgets have finally come in.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Almost as fatal. Millstein called. Looks like New York just shaved a week off portfolio deadline.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You gotta be kidding me.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: I wish I were.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What're they trying to do, strangle us to death?! Does Dennis know?

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Called him first thing.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Alright. Get Dennis and the others and call a portfolio meeting for lunch today. Marlene, see if you can move production review to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MARLENE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: And would you get my wife on the phone? (to Stan) Thanks, Stan. Frank pats Stan on the shoulder and marches through the l wood-paneled door of his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank drops his briefcase and sits down heavily at the la handsomely ornamented desk.  22. He takes a breath before turning and quietly opening a lo drawer, pulling out a quart of Jack Daniels and pouring a swig into his coffee. As he stashes it away we hear

dialogues.speaker: MARLENE
dialogues.text: (on intercom) Sir? I have Mrs. Whitaker on line 1.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thank you, Marlene. Frank takes a slurp, swallows and pushes line 1 on his ph

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Cathy, is that you, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy speaks to Frank from the phone in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Did you forget something?... Oh, Frank... I’m sorry, dear... No, I understand... I just wish you wouldn’t overwork yourself, Frank. Especially after... I know - I know, dear... I will... See you then... Goodbye, dear. Cathy hangs up the phone and starts back into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I’m terribly sorry for the interruptions. Where was it you wanted me?

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Just one more at the fireplace. Cathy walks over to the fireplace where she puts one hand the mantle and turns toward the photographer.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Right there. Now smile. Cathy smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEACOCK
dialogues.text: Isn't that darling.  23.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Hold it... FLASH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We descend from a moonlit night past the Hartford skyline the awning of Sammy's Steakhouse, where Frank and four ST MEMBERS are just emerging.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (slightly slurred) Well I guess that about wraps it up (shaking hands) ) Bob, Rick. Gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MEMBER 1
dialogues.text: You're sure you're alright getting home, sir?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thank you, Davis. But as 2nd in command of the US McMillan I do feel equipped to locate my car without cover.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MEMBER 1
dialogues.text: Very good, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Bright and early gentlemen! They say goodnight and we follow Frank as he proceeds dow the pink, lamplit blocks of downtown Hartford. He passes teenagers clumped in cars, making out. He passes a HOOKER.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Where ya headed, tiger? Frank looks away as he passes. When he looks up again he The marquee of a movie theater glowing up ahead.  24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank approaches the tungsten awning of the old, 20's-sty cinema, currently featuring half-price double-bills. He stops. The marquee reads: THREE FACES OF EVE and MIRACLE IN THE RAIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ONSCREEN: We are in the middle of THREE FACES OF EVE. Ray Burr is questioning one of Joanne Woodward's more timid personalities. Frank is walking in from the rear of the theater. He stop along the back wall and stands watching, muted in shadow Edward Hopper's usherette. ONSCREEN: Joanne Woodward is becoming agitated. She start switching into another personality. A dark-haired man is getting up from his seat and walking the direction of the Gentleman's Lounge. Frank notices hi pausing a moment at the foot of the small, carpeted stair just as a second man approaches. The dark-haired man spot the second one and proceeds briskly down the stairs. The second man follows, looking around nervously as he goes. Frank stares darkly down the empty corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy sits in the lilac glow of her lamp-lit writing tabl addresses party gunshots can be heard from downstairs. Cathy turns the face of her desk-clock to see the time. I reads 10:36.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (getting up) Oh, for heavens sake... DAVID!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music escorts us from the dark of the living room to the chestnut glow of the den where David sits watching television.  25. Sybil inventories serving ware in the dining room, as Cat makes her way downstairs with writing tablet and pen.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: David, this is the third time I've told you to turn that infernal racket off and get into bed! Do you know what time it is?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Mother please can I just this once stay up and watch the -

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: No, David, you most certainly may not and that is final.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (reluctantly turning it off) Ah, jeez...

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: That's not the sort of language we use in this house! Now march! And don't forget to wash your teeth! As David swaggers off Cathy straightens up the couch.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, Sybil, be sure and check dinner forks as well. I seem to recall being short last year.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: I thought it was salad forks we were short on. Cathy begins closing drapes in the living room windows.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Perhaps you're right. Whatever it was, I'd like to try and order a set before the party.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: That shouldn't be a problem.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You know, Sybil, I think this may just turn out to be our best one yet.  26.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Well I'm sure Mr. Whitaker will be extremely proud. Cathy turns off a lamp by the window and parts the drapes moment. She glances out into the silent, blue-edged night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man on a ladder is replacing the letters on the theater marquee as Frank files out of the theater amid the strang week-night crowd. He stops a moment beneath the canopy of bulbs. There's a trill of laughter from down the street and Fran turns. The two men from the movie theater are walking off, one o them laughing. They turn the corner. Frank squints, looking after. And with a frown of curiosi and some unsteadiness, he begins to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men are crossing the shadowy side-street. One of can still be heard as they approach a dark, inconspicuous door, a few steps down from street-level. They open it, sending a sudden flood of green into the darkness, then quickly vanish inside. Frank stares after, stuck between intrigue and fear. He follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran's is a small, burgundy-walled “gentlemen's bar', wit black upholstery and a mint-green light embalming its wel groomed clientele - most of whom take subtle notice of Fr as he enters the room. Out of nowhere a voice is heard -

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Identification please.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (turning, startled) What?  27. A thin man in his 50's with a pencil-thin mustache stands beside the door.

dialogues.speaker: MAN WITH MUSTACHE
dialogues.text: Identification, drivers license.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh. Sure. Frank shows him his wallet

dialogues.speaker: MAN WITH MUSTACHE
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. Have a pleasant evening.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thank you. Frank proceeds cautiously into the room, heading to the b A SPANISH BARTENDER accent nods slowly as he approaches.

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir? What can I get you this evening?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Just a Johnny Walker, please. Neat.

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Frank takes out a cigarette and lights it. He glances sti across the room. The plucked and coiffed patrons, seated mostly alone, gla back with the same stiff, self-consciousness. The men fro the theater sit in some corner rapt in conversation. Frank's drink is set on the bar and he takes a fast, deep sip, shiny with perspiration. Frank puts down a bill and takes a long, relaxing drag of his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: One more of the same. Frank looks over and sees a clean-cut BLOND MAN (early 30 at the bar. He exhales. The blond man glances over and smiles cautiously. Frank smiles cautiously back  28.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: There you are, sir. The blond man remains looking at Frank a moment before picking up his drink and starting back to his table. Frank watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank closes the front door behind him and starts slowly the stairs of the house, black on shadowy blue, as a slow burden of music rises. He stops at the foot of his bedroom door and stares at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy, copper and blue, asleep in bed. Music lightens as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We float out from a newspaper photograph of Frank and Cat kissing in the latest Hartford Weekly Gazette to reveal Eleanor, reading aloud from the paper. The door to the ho is open as Cathy and her arriving guests, DOREEN and NANC stand around listening, having obviously been stopped in their tracks to do so. Cathy holds a lilac scarf under he chin as a feisty wind whips through the trees and sends a circus of leaves through the sky.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: ‘So does the fabled maxim hold that behind every great man there resides a great lady? In this case - wife, mother and Mrs. Magnovox herself - Cathleen Whitaker proves that it does, a woman as devoted to her family as she is kind to Negroes’!! They burst into laughter.  29.

dialogues.speaker: DOREEN
dialogues.text: To Negroes?!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (grabbing the paper) Let me see that! Oh my heavens. What on earth was that woman thinking?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: How did that come up?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Cathy? Oh she's been liberal ever since she played summer stock at college with all those steamy Jewish boys! Why do you think they used to call her red!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh for heaven sakes, come inside. Before Joe McCarthy comes driving by! Eleanor laughs and Cathy hands her back the paper.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Here. Suddenly a strong gust of wind sweeps Cathy's scarf right her head and up over the side of the house.

dialogues.speaker: DOREEN
dialogues.text: Uh-oh!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, no! I love that scarf!

dialogues.speaker: DOREEN
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sure it just blew behind the house somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, for heaven's sake. They continue back inside the house.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: This really isn't your day, is it?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: So did they really call you ‘red’?  30. Eleanor laughs some more.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh Nancy, honestly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ladies are just finishing lunch, a bit tipsy from the daiquiris.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Can I get anyone another daiquiri?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh no. One's my limit.

dialogues.speaker: DOREEN
dialogues.text: Better not.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: El? Eleanor holds out her glass. Cathy smiles, refilling it.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Thanks doll. (takes a sip) Alright now girls, no more beating around the bush. Nancy?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Come on now. Can't be that bad.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Alright. (she smiles bashfully) Well... Mike insists on once a week. The laddies giggle, except for Cathy, who stands holding pitcher of daiquiris.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Ah, you got off easy!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Once a week?  31.

dialogues.speaker: DOREEN
dialogues.text: Yea, you’re lucky. Ron’s more like two or three.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Really? Three?

dialogues.speaker: DOREEN
dialogues.text: And how.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: That’s nothing. Girlfriend of mine? (to Cathy) Shirley Dawson - (back to everyone) Her husband? Every night-o-the- week... plus three times more on the weekend! Can you imagine? Cathy returns the pitcher to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh, my.

dialogues.speaker: DOREEN
dialogues.text: How long have they been married?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Well, long enough! Seven years? Eight? Doreen and Nancy break into more giggles as Cathy stands moment, reflected in thought in the marbled mirror, a not music accompanying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy stands in front of her house waiving goodbye to Eleanor, Doreen and Nancy, who make their way to their ca

dialogues.speaker: DOREEN
dialogues.text: It was lovely, Cathleen!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thanks, girls.

dialogues.speaker: DOREEN
dialogues.text: Bye, now.  32.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Chicken was divine.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thanks, El.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I’1l1 call you tomorrow!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Thanks again, hon! It was all too divine!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thanks, El. I'll call you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Bye! Cathy is about to turn back into the house when she puts hand to her head, remembering her scarf. She glances over toward the side of the house and starts slowly down the f steps, glancing around the yard as she goes. By now the wind has died down and a pale opal light has t the edge off the sun. A soft spell of music begins. She doesn't see it along the front hedges and continues o the side of the house. She turns the corner, glancing up the roof. Suddenly

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Could this possibly - Cathy turns with a start. Raymond is standing along the side of the house holding h lilac scarf.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: No - You found it!  33.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Yes - It was... (starts walking toward her) hanging off one of the birch's down front.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: It's just been so windy. I was just going back in the house when it just - Raymond hands Cathy the scarf.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: . sailed off my head - Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: I had a feeling it might have been yours.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Who else could have been so absentminded?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: No. The color. Just seemed right.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well thank you, Mr. Deagan. For finding it.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Please. Call me Raymond.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you. Raymond. She smiles and they begin walking back to the front yard.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Everything looks wonderful by the way.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Well good. Pop’s a tough act to follow when it comes to his work. But I think we got everything pretty under control. Cathy looks at him a moment.  34.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I’m sure it hasn’t been easy. Taking over for your father so quickly.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Well I guess between pa’s business my shop, and looking after my little girl, there’s not much time left for reflecting.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I didn't know you had children.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Just the one. Sarah's her name.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: And how old is Sarah?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Eleven years old, yea. And the sun and the moon to me.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well I'm sure she's a lovely child. You and your wife must be very proud.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Well, Mrs. Deagan - my wife - she passed away when Sarah was about five.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh Raymond. I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Well. Thank you. We do - we do just fine, Sarah and I. (reaching for his wallet) I have a - picture somewhere... (opening it for Cathy) There. That's Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, she's darling. Look at those eyes... And what's this I hear about a shop?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: The plant shop? Yea. It's just a little place, down on Hawthorn. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAYMOND( cont'd) Started out as a service for gardeners, ordering plants and fertilizer. ‘Til I opened the store. ‘Bout six years ago. The only thing that business degree's been good for yet.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well that's marvelous, Raymond. You should be very proud.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Well. If you’re ever in the neighborhood you be sure and stop by. We have some lovely houseplants.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well I certainly will.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Alright then. She smiles goodbye and walks back into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy closes the door behind her. Right away we hear Sybi from the kitchen door.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: (off) Mrs. Whitaker? I have that list whenever you’re ready!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Sybil. I’1l come get it now. Where has this day gone to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From just outside the blaze of the kitchen we find Cathy Sybil busily serving dinner to the children.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Elbows off the table, David!

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Eeuu - I hate those!  36.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Janice. But for a growing girl, who needs her vitamins and is studying ballet -

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Oh mother! You said... You said -

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I said we would discuss it and we discussed it. Now I don’t want to hear another word about it. I certainly don't like thinking I've raised such spoiled children.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What do you mean children? I'm not the one who wants some dopey ballet shoes!

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Slippers! The telephone rings. Sybil is carrying a tray of food.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: If that's your father... Don't worry, Sybil, I'll get it. (she picks up the phone) Hello? Frank? You haven't left?... Oh no, not again... I know Frank but every week... I know, I know darling... I won't... Alright... Goodnight, dear. (she hangs up the phone)

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What! He's not coming home again?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Father never wants to come home!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh Janice, he most certainly does. It's just a terribly busy time for your father right now, and he's under a great deal of strain.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to Janice) Yea!  37.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You know what, Sybil? Wrap up a plate for Mr. Whitaker. I'm just gonna go and take it over there myself.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: All the way downtown?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: It's really not so far. Anyway, the children are nearly through, and knowing Mr. Whitaker, I'll at least be sparing him another night of pretzels and coffee. Cathy picks up her coat from a corner chair and starts ou the door as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy, emerging through the shimmer of a revolving door, quiet dissonance emerges, building slowly throughout the scene. She walks across the large marble-floored lobby, Tupperware in hand, to the night-watch's table.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I'm just dropping something off to my husband on the twelfth floor Mr. Whitaker. The NIGHT-WATCH motions her in and Cathy continues briskl the elevators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors open. Cathy steps out onto the darkene floor and starts down the central corridor toward the executive suite. As she approaches the outer office she realizes there is one else in sight, no lights, no sign of work.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (to herself, perplexed) Frank?  38. She glances around as she continues, doubtfully, in the direction of his office. Then she notices A soft strip of light coming from beneath his office door

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) Oh, Frank... In a rush of wifely sympathy she walks up to the door and politely opens it.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank - ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instantly she sees it: a shirtless blond man with loosene pants locked in a writhing kiss with another man in shirtsleeves, who appears to be fondling him. Immediately they turn and jolt apart. It takes her a moment to regist that the man in shirtsleeves is Frank. All at once Cathy gasps, pulling back and turning, droppi her Tupperware. She shuts her eyes and struggles for brea Inside we can hear the men scrambling to dress, knocking something over in the process. Suddenly Cathy turns facing the door, reeling, horrified. Music burns with the weight of realization as she starts stepping slowly, staring out in confusion and disbelief. She glimpses something through the crack of the door and stops. Frank catches sight of her from inside. Cathy stares. He looks down. Suddenly the blond man slips out past him, darting briskly down the hall. He disappears down the stairwell where we can hear his echoey steps slowly fadin away . All at once Cathy turns and runs, music returning with thunder and storm.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Cathy!  39. She runs down the hall to the elevator, bangs on the butt until it opens and throws herself inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy gasps for air inside the dim, mirror-lined elevator trying to pull her hair over her eyes and shut out the wo forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music bathes the shadowy quiet of the Whitaker exterior, darkness brushed blue with moonlight, as we glide in slow toward the living room window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music continues as we creep in slowly on Cathy silhouette against the glass, frozen in thought. Suddenly there’s th sound of keys at the door and we stop, silent. Cathy does move. Frank quietly shuts the door behind him and turns around. Dead, eerie silence. He removes his coat, hangs it on the rack, and takes a qu out of the closet. He turns and stops, sensing something. Then he sees her. Cathy just stares. But there’s a new kind of death in her face. Frank drops his head. He remains still for several second Finally

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (from a strange distance) Mr. Maynard... left an estimate... for the roof. I put it in the kitchen. (silence) Twelve hundred something. I assume you’11 want - (silence) a second opinion...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy -

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I can’t - Silence.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I know. Silence. He drops his head.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don’t - (doesn’t finish)

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don't even... Frank looks up. He sighs with resignation.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: See... Once. Long time ago. Long long time ago. I had... problems. I just figured... that was - that was it. (shaking his head) I never... imagined...

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You had... problems?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You never... spoke to anyone? A doctor?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: No one? Frank shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I don't... I don't understand. 40.  41.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don't either.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What if... I mean there must be people who - who...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: There must be. Frank suddenly seems a hundred miles away.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank? Frank can barely look at her let alone respond.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Because... (suddenly shaky) Otherwise, I just - I don't know what - Oh Frank! Soft music begins. Frank closes his eyes and quietly nods Cathy exhales a tiny breath of relief.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (softly) Thank you. He slowly-turns and Cathy watches as he starts up the sta music expanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last Autumn leaves are falling on this bright, bluste afternoon in the Hartford business district. Cathy's car be seen turning onto the main road and continuing into to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The large, modern medical complex stretches out against c blue skies and white clouds. Down below we see Cathy pull into the Municipal lot. The white-capped attendant hands a ticket, raises the gate and smiles as she proceeds in.  42. Cathy walks up to the front of one of the buildings, chec her watch and glances around for Frank. In a small park opposite, a young couple can be seen lean against a tree, kissing. The girl pulls away but the boy pursues eagerly, stroking the girl's hair and whispering her ear. Cathy watches, closer (with a rear-projected background). The boy tries kissing her again, but the girl turns away, glancing toward Cathy self-consciously. Cathy looks down. She checks her watch again and glances around one more time for Frank. We see him now, just crossing the street Cathy waves, starting over in his direction. They meet an begin walking up the slope of stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RECEPTIONIST is swinging open the door of the waiting room.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Whitaker .?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Yes. Cathy and Frank get up from their chairs. DR. Bowman, an imposing man in his fifties with a distinc streak of white in his hair, is just stepping through the door as music fades.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: This is Dr. Bowman.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: (shaking Frank's hand firmly) Mr. Whitaker? How do you. (politely taking Cathy's) Mrs. Whitaker? How lovely.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you.  43.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Whitaker, Mrs. Whitaker. As someone who's been around numerous couples like yourselves, I realize how difficult these things can be at times, particularly at the beginning. It's been said the first steps are always the hardest ones to take. But as I'm oft to remind my patients, without them, of course, why we wouldn't even be walking! So allow me first to commend you both... for taking those steps today.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you, doctor.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Before we sit down, are there any questions I can answer? Cathy looks to Frank who vaguely gestures ‘no.’

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: No? Alright. (to Frank) I suppose we may as well get started. Dr. Bowman gestures to the door and Cathy starts in first

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Actually, Mrs. Whitaker, I think it might be best if your husband and I conversed - in private.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh. In private. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: I think it's best.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Certainly. Then I'll - see you later, dear.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: See you later. And they close the door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy is motionless for a moment before turning back into waiting room and sitting down. She smiles at the receptio who vaguely smiles back. She looks back at the door.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Today, the general attitude regarding this sort, of behavior is, naturally, more modern, more scientific than it's ever been before. After all, we're not living in the dark ages. But for those who do seek treatment, who possess the will and desire to lead normal lives, there still remains only a scant, 5-to-30 percent rate of success. For complete heterosexual conversion. Interestingly, for many, it's the treatment itself that often changes the patient's mind. One thing is certain. A successful outcome is only ever achieved when it's what the patient himself desires more than anything else in the world.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What does it - comprise of? The treatment.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Treatment is usually comprised of psychiatric sessions, twice a week sometimes more.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Just - talking?

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Though some patients have explored additional, more behavioral methods.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Behavioral?  45.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Electro-shock aversion therapy, for instance, or hormonal re-balancing procedures. But neither of these would be part of any standardized treatment. Silence. Frank looks down in thought.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: I know it can all seem rather daunting at first. (leaning back in his chair) I suggest you take some time, think over the various options we discussed, discuss it with your wife -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No, I - I already know - I want to go ahead. Begin treatment. Frank tries to gather his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I can't - let this thing destroy my life - my family's life! I know it's a sickness because it makes me feel - despicable, dirty. I promise you Dr. Bowman, I'm gonna beat this thing. I'm gonna break it. So help me God. The doctor is listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door swings open and Cathy turns to see Frank and Dr. Bowman step into the waiting room.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: So why don't you go ahead and confirm the times we discussed with Rosalyn. And I'll see you here same time next Tuesday. (they shake)

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thank you, doctor.  46. Cathy listens on, beaming with pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Whitaker. (leaning out toward Cathy) Mrs. Whitaker!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you, doctor! Frank walks right past her. Cathy turns to catch up with

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy joins Frank in the paneled elevator. The door close a soft stir of music begins. Cathy looks over at Frank wh stares ahead, blankly.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I'm just proud of you, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Don't say that.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well I am. And he seems like a very decent man, Dr. Bowman. Don't you think? He doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don't know, Cathleen. I suppose he's decent. The elevator doors open and Frank stalks through the lobb and out the door, music thickening. Cathy follows.  47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Cathy walk out of the building into a strong wi Behind them an obscure, REAR-PROJECTED Hartford feels a million miles away.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: But Frank, you must have liked him enough to want to see him again.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Who else am I going see?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well - I'm sure there are numerous doctors - in Hartford or in Springfield - if you don't - if you aren't certain about - He stops sharply and turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Look! I just want to get the whole fucking thing over with! Can you understand that?! Cathy stares at him in shock and fear.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (eyes filling) Frank! Please don't - Frank takes her hand. Suddenly his eyes fill as well.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm sorry. He embraces her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Cathy, I'm so sorry. The music opens up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull out from a large, framed version of the Mr.& Mrs. Magnavox ad, to a view of the whole bustling floor  48. The elevator doors open and we follow Frank as he walks d the central aisle toward his office. He nods to the regular cycle of greetings ('Good morning, Whitaker... Morning, sir'). He approaches Kitty's desk.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Whitaker.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (a bit faintly) Kitty.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: I hope you have a pleasant day, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (glancing back vaguely) Thank you. He continues on to his office. There, he discovers Marlene standing at her desk holding broken desk lamp.

dialogues.speaker: MARLENE
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Whitaker.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Marlene.

dialogues.speaker: MARLENE
dialogues.text: I found this in the cupboard, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: MARLENE
dialogues.text: Your desk lamp. Sir. The one that was missing. Frank lingers a moment, absently.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: MARLENE
dialogues.text: Should I have it repaired, sir?  49.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes - (continuing into his office) Thank you, Marlene.

dialogues.speaker: MARLENE
dialogues.text: Uh - Mr. Whitaker, Mr. Fine's been - The door closes behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank stands a moment facing the door in silence.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: (off) Frank? Frank turns around to see Stan seated on a leather couch the window.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Didn't see you there!

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: (slight beat) Everything alright?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: with me? (brushing it off) Oh... Frank sits down at his desk as Stan gets up, holding a la flat folder.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What's up.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Just picked up the galleys from the printer.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: How do they look?

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Great. Just great.  50.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Fine. Fine. (flipping through his appointment book) Why'n't you leave ‘em here and I'll - have a look the first chance I get.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: (slightly perplexed) Sure. Stan walks over to the desk and sets down the folder.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: You'll... let me know what you think?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Course I will. You're first on my list.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: (before leaving) So what's it gonna take to get you back on that course, anyway? We haven't seen you for weeks!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I know it. I've just been...

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Sunday. No excuses.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: I'm holding you to it! Stan leaves Frank alone at his desk. Staring straight ahe he reaches down to the bottom drawer and pulls out the bo of Scotch. He unscrews the top, closes his eyes and takes long, dark swig, music rising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a cold, overcast day in the quiet, tree-lined neighborhood of the Blue Hills district, as Cathy and Ele emerge from the house carrying serving trays. Cathy's car parked in the driveway of Eleanor's modern Ranch-style ho

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thanks again, El.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You sure that's all I can give you?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. The caterers should have everything. I just thought a few extras would be nice. They approach Cathy's car.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Oh - And don't forget! The art show's Saturday so start working on Frank tonight. Cathy opens the car door and starts putting the trays ins

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I swear he's the kind of man you have to pin messages to!

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Though I'm sorry to say Mona Lauder will be attending. Turns out her uncle's in town, some hot-shot art- dealer from New York. I think I met him at one of Mona's soiree's. A bit flowery for my tastes.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Oh, you know. A touch light on his feet?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You mean...  52.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Yes, darling. One of those. of course I could be mistaken. Just an impression I got.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You don't care for them particularly?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Well, no, not particularly. Not that I actually know any. Call me old-fashioned, I just like all the men I'm around to be all men. Say! Why the third degree?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: It's not the third degree, I just - (climbing into her car) I'm interested, that's all. In your views. Eleanor doesn't look convinced.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I read an article recently. Ina magazine. (she closes the car door) - What?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Nothing! I'm just delighted to see you taking interest in yet another civic cause! I can see it now: "Cathleen Whitaker and her kindness to Homosexuals'!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh - that word. Cathy begins pulling out.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: See you Sunday. And bring Frank!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I’ll try. Eleanor waves and starts back into the house as Cathy dri off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon shadows stretch across the Whitaker’s block as Cathy turns the corner. She pulls into the driveway just Frank is getting out of his car and David, dressed in his baseball uniform, and Janice, in ballet clothes, come run to greet him.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Father’s home! Father’s home!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well look who’s here. The little ballerina herself.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hi-ya, pop!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (to David) Whaduya say, kiddo? Cathy steps out of her car just as Sybil appears to meet

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What a lovely surprise, having you home at a decent hour. Thank you Sybil.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Marlene had me set for another dinner meeting but I just said to reschedule.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, Frank. I’m so pleased you did. They embrace and Frank kisses her as the whole family fol Sybil into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Whitaker family are in the midst of a spirited dinner though it's clear all the enthusiasm in the room has begu drain Frank of his.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Then Billy Hutchison stole a pass at the ten yard line, pop. Ran it all the way for a touch down. You shoulda seen it!  54.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Father, wanna see my routine for the ballet recital?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I was talking to pop!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Children. Give your father a moment to eat his dinner. (to Frank) Another lambchop, dear?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You sure? I have plenty in the oven.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Thank you. Small silence.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We're playing Lincoln on Saturday, pop. If you're not working.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh heavens, that reminds me! Darling, this Saturday is that reception I told you about, for the modern art show Eleanor's group was sponsoring. You remember?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh God.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I know how you hate these things but I simply have to go and Eleanor pleaded with me to ask you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What about me! No one cares one bit what I'm doing Saturday! Like playing one of the toughest teams in the whole entire league!  55.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: David I'm sorry but this one Saturday your mother has an engagement that simply can't be changed -

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Pop could come. Cathy looks at Frank who is looking down.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Couldn't you, pop?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: We'll see, David. No one talks for several seconds.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Janice, would you please pass the butter? Janice passes the butter to her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank watches TV from bed. Cathy sits at her vanity doing hundred strokes, looking over at him while brushing.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (brief silence) Did you see him?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yea.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yesterday.  56.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You didn't say a word. He continues staring at the TV.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: So how was it? With Bowman? Did you feel -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It's fine.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (putting down the brush coaxing) And there's nothing more you care to share with your very own adoring wife?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Cathleen, what I discuss with this doctor. It's private. That's - part of it. Alright? I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I understand, dear. I do. Cathy looks at him a moment before lifting up the brush a turning back to the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh and Frank, wait'll you see the hors d'oeuvres! The caterers are doing such a marvelous job. I think you're going to be very pleased this year, darling. I really do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A frolic of music rises as we survey a busy corner within Hartford cultural district A small bustle of ladies and their husbands are milling around the entrance to a spacious, private gallery. The easled sign in the front window reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, Cathy comes running up to the door of the galler

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy squeezes past clusters of visitors holding glasses wine when she spots Eleanor standing in front of a large Christmas tree. Eleanor is chatting with MONA LAUDER, an imposing, chinless brunette (fortyish), and MR. FARNSWORT Mona’s uncle, a rotund middle-aged man with died ginger h and a waxed mustache.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Eleanor - darling! I’m so sorry I’m late.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Cathleen!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Hello Mona.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Darling, I want to introduce you to my uncle, Morris Farnsworth, a wickedly successful Gotham art dealer who was kind enough to attend our provincial little gathering. Morris darling, allow me to introduce my dear little friend Cathleen Whitaker - whose face and civic fancies are hardly strangers to the society pages of Hartford!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh Mona, really. You must ignore her, Mr. Farnsworth. Mr. Farnsworth extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: FARNSWORTH
dialogues.text: (rather affected) Charmed.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I hope you enjoy your stay.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Morris was just telling us the most delightful tale. All about a forged Rembrandt!  58.

dialogues.speaker: FARNSWORTH
dialogues.text: Well there's really not much more to it than that. You can only imagine my utter disdain in discovering the gifts of so masterful an impersonator in as base and uncivilized a character as the man ultimately convicted of the crime.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: It's fascinating, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Cathy, darling, don't let us keep you. I know you want to see the show.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I am dying to see it.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Oh yes. It's simply charming. Eleanor you should be so proud.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Why thank you, Mona.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Lovely meeting you, Mr. Farnsworth.

dialogues.speaker: FARNSWORTH
dialogues.text: Likewise, my dear. Cathy throws Eleanor a little smile as she starts off int the gallery.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Cathy stands in front of a beautiful Picasso ‘crying woma Suddenly - FLASH! - Cathy turns to see Mrs. Leacock standing beside her photographer.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEACOCK
dialogues.text: Pardon me, dear, but it was too lovely to resist: Wife of Hartford Executive Communing With Picasso!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Mrs. Leacock. Lovely to see you again.  59.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEACOCK
dialogues.text: And how is that charming husband of yours?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: He's very well, thank you - Cathy stops suddenly, spotting someone across the room. Raymond is standing with his daughter SARAH (age 11), lea over her and discussing one of the pictures on the wall. surprisingly, they're the only black faces in the room.)

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Mrs. Leacock, would you excuse me a moment?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEACOCK
dialogues.text: Certainly, dear. Cathy smiles and starts over to Raymond and his little gi as Mrs. Leacock and the photographer observe. Raymond looks up and sees Cathy approaching. He smiles an stands.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Mrs. Whitaker! Hello!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Raymond. What a tremendous surprise - finding you here. Is this your daughter?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Yep. This is Sarah. Sarah, this is Mrs. Whitaker. Mrs. Whitaker owns one of the gardens I look after

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Hello, Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: (spotting something out front) Say, Sarah, isn't that Hutch and his little brother I see, playing out front?  60. Raymond directs Sarah's attention to the front of the gal where Billy Hutchison. (HUTCH, age 11) and two other whit boys can be seen through the glass, playing with paper airplanes.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: You remember them, don't you, baby? Sarah shakes her head, sullenly.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Sure you do. The day we went to Mrs. Hutchison's house.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (softly) Oh, yea.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: What do you say about going out and seeing if they'd like to play for a little while? How does that sound? Sarah looks at her father. It's clear it's the very last thing she wants to do, but is too shy to say anything in front of Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Aww, there's nothing to be afraid of.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (softly) I know...

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: It's only polite to say hello to people you've met in the past. Ah, go on, give it a try. For daddy. Sarah looks down, turns slowly and starts reluctantly tow the front of the gallery.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Attagirl!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh Raymond, she’s lovely.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Thank you.  61.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: And how wonderful of you to expose her - to art and culture this way.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Well, my mother, she was always trying to expose my brothers and I to the finer things, and we fought her every step of the way. I guess I’m sort of making up for bad behavior.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: But how on earth did you hear about this show?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Well I do read the papers.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well of course you do. I just meant - it was such a coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: I know. I was just teasing you.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (slightly lower voice) Because you know I’m not prejudiced. Raymond smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (quite serious) My husband and I have always believed in equal right for the Negro, and support the NACP.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Well I’m glad to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I just - I wanted you to know.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Well thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Not at all.  62. As they start into the final room of the gallery we see S through the window outside, watching as the boys try unsuccessfully to launch their paper airplane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on Hutch's paper airplane as his friend, Tommy, giv it a throw.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Go! The plane nosedives and Hutch goes to get it.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Straighter, Tommy! You gotta throw it straighter. And hard! One, two, three - GO! Tommy throws it hard but it sputters down once again. Sarah giggles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: It's too heavy! The boys stop and turn.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: On the end. Your airplane!

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Who asked you?! C’mon, Bobby. Hutch motions to the others and the boys start back into gallery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutch and his brother return to their parents as Sarah watches from outside, alone.

dialogues.speaker: MEANWHILE
dialogues.text: Cathy and Raymond are looking at a Miro.  63.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: So what is your opinion on modern art?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: It's hard to put into words really. I just know what I care for and what I" don't. Like this - I'm not sure how you pronounce it - Mirra?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Miro.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Miro. I don't know why but I just adore it. The feeling it gives. I know that sounds terribly vague.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: No. It actually confirms something I've always wondered about modern art, abstract art.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: That perhaps it's just picking up where religious art left off. You know. Trying to somehow show you divinity, put it up there on the wall. The modern artist just pares it down to the most basic elements of shape and color. But when you look at that Miro, you feel it just the same.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Why that's lovely, Raymond. We hear the brief shriek of a woman's laugh. Cathy turns Mona Lauder, Mr. Farnsworth and two other women, one stif her giggles, snickering amongst themselves over Cathy and Eleanor, who is standing listening to an ELDERLY WOMAN, a notices the commotion.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN
dialogues.text: To tell you the truth, I was rather shocked by the prices. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELDERLY WOMAN(cont 'd) But then I've always preferred the work of the masters... Rembrandt, Michelangelo - Eleanor spots Cathy saying goodbye to Raymond and startin off down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I'm terribly sorry - Would you excuse me a moment?

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Certainly. Eleanor starts after Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Cathleen!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: El, honey. It all looks just marvelous - Eleanor whisks Cathy to the side.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Cathy, who on earth was that man? You have the whole place ina clamor!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh for heavens sake, why? Because of that ridiculous story?
