dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (squinting off at Raymond) Who is he? Raymond is now introducing Sarah to a smiling, middle-age woman in a hat.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: His name's Raymond Deagan. He's Otis Deagan's son.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Your gardener?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Yes. He passed away very recently and Raymond's taken over his business.  65.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Well you certainly seem on familiar terms with the man.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh what does that mean? Familiar terms? He happens to have some very enlightening views on Miro. (glancing at her watch) Oh, jeepers, would you look at the time! El, I have to fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start walking toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I'm having the carpets cleaned for tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: What time are the caterers showing?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: They said four.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I'll come early too. For moral support!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You're a doll. Cathy waves bye and dashes out of the gallery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music accompanies a slow and stately ascent upon the Whit house, trimmed with cars and bursting from inside with th exuberance of the annual company party. We can even hear distant clamor of merriment and laughter churning from within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house, impeccably decorated, is swarming with people evening dress, drinking, smoking, chatting, laughing. An overstuffed Christmas tree glistens in the corner as an endless parade of hors d'oeuvres are passed solemnly by t all-black, formally uniformed, serving staff.  66. Cathy shimmers in a gown of sapphire blue, standing surrounded at one end of the room, while Frank stands wit drink in hand, surrounded at the other. We see various faces from the Magnavox office, including Marlene. Cathy is listening to a middle-aged Elderly Woma

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Not to say that I'm against integration mind you. I do believe it's the Christian thing to. But I still say what happened in Little Rock could just as easily have happened here in Hartford. A stout, red-faced man answers.

dialogues.speaker: RED-FACED MAN
dialogues.text: Nonsense!

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN
dialogues.text: And why is that?

dialogues.speaker: RED-FACED MAN
dialogues.text: Well for one thing, there's no Governor Faubus in Connecticut. But the main reason - They're no Negroes! (laughs) Two of the serving staff close enough to have heard his remark continue serving. DICK DAWSON, a tall, strapping man in his mid-30's, is leaning on a chair beside Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: No, but I do hear there are some rather dangerous pro-integration types. Right here in Hartford!

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Dangerous?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Some very attractive ones in fact. Noted, I'm told, for their kindness to Negroes!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (slapping his arm) Oh Dick, stop! Where on earth did you hear about that?  67.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Shirley read it to me.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I should have known.

dialogues.speaker: RED-FACED MAN
dialogues.text: What's all this?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Absolutely nothing! Here, let me freshen those. Cathy takes Dick and the red-faced man's glasses and star off toward the bar. Frank is at the couch with Stan Fine, Doreen and her husband RON. As Cathy passes, Stan calls o to her.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: By golly there she is now! Prettiest gal in the room!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, Stan! Liquor does bring out the Texan in you. I just hope Eleanor isn't listening.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: (putting an arm around her) So what if she is! I still say Frank's the luckiest guy in town.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Here, here! Frank is hunched over listening, noticeably intoxicated.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (thinking he's being witty) Smoke and mirrors, fellas! That's all it is. You should see her without her face on! Frank laughs at his own joke and a few join in awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: DOREEN
dialogues.text: Erank!  68.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: No, he's absolutely right. We ladies are never really what we appear. And every girl has her secrets!

dialogues.speaker: DOREEN
dialogues.text: I'll say.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (thrusting his glass at her) Well how ‘bout this girl going and getting her husband another drink? How ‘bout that?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (still smiling) You don't think you might have - already had enough, darling?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No, I don't think I've already had -

dialogues.speaker: DOREEN
dialogues.text: (interrupting, raising her glass) Well I'd just like to take a moment to raise a glass to our marvelous host and hostess and another glorious Annual Party at the Whitaker's! To Frank and Cathy, truly Mr. and Mrs. Magnavox! Everyone around them raises their glasses ‘To Frank and Cathy’ and toasts. Cathy and Frank smile and nod at their guests, but the strain is evident

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you... Now who can I freshen up? Ron?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: STAN
dialogues.text: Me.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I think you're fresh enough. Cathy starts off toward the bar. Sybil is crossing with a tray.
Wonderful party, Cathleen.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Here, Mrs. Whitaker those.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sybil. let me take Eleanor approaches Cathy as she finishes giving Sybil the empty glasses.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Cathy?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Hi. Eleanor pulls her aside, by a window. him so

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Honey? Is everything alright?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Frank. I've never seen soused.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, no. He's just been hard lately. He's been tremendous strain.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You sure that's all?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You'd tell me if there more?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Of course I would. - working so under such was anything  70. Eleanor puts a hand on Cathy's back as they start back in the party.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: By the way, kid. I think we just threw ourselves one class-A swanky function.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: It did turn nicely, didn't it. A WOMAN calls out to Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Cathleen, darling. You've simply outdone yourself - once again!

dialogues.speaker: WHITAKER LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Cathy stands at the door waving goodbye to the last guest (probably Eleanor & Stan)

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thanks for everything! I'll call you tomorrow! Goodnight! Cathy closes the door and steps into the half-darkened ho still strewn with party debris. She takes a deep breath o relief, and notices Eleanor's serving-ware by the bar.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, shoot - I forgot to give Eleanor her servers. Frank sits in an armchair, rouged in shadow. Cathy walks toward the stairs and stops, looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank? He doesn't respond, and she continues on toward the stair

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well, if I do say so myself, I think it was a very lovely party, all considering. She stops to gather her wrap at the foot of the stairs. S looks off a moment, very still.  71.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (quiet and level) I just don't understand. Why it has to turn ugly. In front of our friends. (silence) Honestly, Frank. If you didn't insist on - She stops, hearing something, and turns - Frank is sudden approaching.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What is it - ? But all at once he’s upon her - rolling into her arms and kissing the side of her neck, music rushing. Cathy is stunned, but gradually begins returning his affection.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh Frank... They fold into the couch, kissing, and suddenly Frank is top of her. At first she’s unsettled by his strong urgenc but she allows it to continue, stroking his head and tryi to slow him down. But he becomes only more persistent panting and thrusting and turning red from the effort. Ca closes her eyes and tries to weather it. Then with a sudd half-choked cry, Frank surrenders, turning away from her muttering aloud in exhaustion and defeat

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus! Jesus, what’s happening! I can’t even... Oh God!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank! Frank, it doesn’t matter, darling! The important thing is to keep... trying. Keep -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (sitting up suddenly, his back to her) Don’t -

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank! She puts her hand on his shoulder but he shakes it off.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Don’t. (silence) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK(cont 'd) Because I’m sure - you know - Dick Dawson wouldn’t mind... lending his services every now and again!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, Frank. She reaches for his arm again and he tries to wriggle fre but she holds on.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I mean, you wouldn't mind that so terribly much, would you? Good- lookin’ guy like Dick. Maybe even Stan would pitch in!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (holding tighter) Frank, please. You're the only man I'd ever -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Let go!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You're all men to me, Frank! And all man!

dialogues.speaker: STOPPIT
dialogues.text: Furiously he swipes her hand away and accidentally strike her hard in the face with his cufflink.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (covering her face) Oh, Frank!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Cathy, I'm sorry. I didn't mean to - Cathy grabs a cloth napkin from the coffee table and pres it to her head.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: It's alright. I'm alright. It was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Is it bleeding?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Just the littlest bit.  73.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus. Frank just stands there, helpless.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Perhaps you could get me a little ice, dear.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Ice?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Cathy, I'm...

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I know, dear. It's alright. I'm alright. Frank slowly backs away, toward the kitchen, music expand Cathy just closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy stands before the mirror in her bedroom vanity brus her hair over the small wound on her forehead. She puts d the brush, takes one last look and starts out of her room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Cathy passes an upstairs window she sees Eleanor's car just pulling up to the house. Cathy takes a breath and st down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor is just ringing the doorbell when Cathy opens the door, holding her friend's serving-ware.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Hey there, honey. Listen, I can't stay. I'm meeting Stan for lunch at the club.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: That sounds nice. I can't believe I let you get away last night without these.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: It's cute, your hair that way.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Yea? I experimented. Here.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: It's adorable. As Cathy hands the servers to Eleanor a serving spoon fal out.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Whoopsie! Cathy picks it up from the ground and puts its back in th dish.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Thanks. Eleanor smiles at Cathy. Suddenly she stops smiling.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Cathy? Cathy's hair no longer conceals the bruise on her forehea

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: What happened to your head? Cathy's hand flies up to cover it

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Nothing, I - hit the door. It was the silliest thing. Eleanor continues staring with concern.  75.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Did something happen - between you and Frank?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Cathy I'm your best friend.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Nothing happened. Nothing at all.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Oh, Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (suddenly quivery) Eleanor!

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (looking hard at her) Cathy I'm your dearest and closest friend in the world. You can call me. Day or night. You hear? Cathy nods. Eleanor remains looking, worriedly at her friend. Then sh sighs and turns to go. Cathy watches, unable to move. She can't contain it any longer and starts after - but stops herself again. Eleanor is climbing into her car. She shuts the door. Cathy turns around facing her house, eyes flooding, as we hear Eleanor driving off. Not ready to go back in, she proceeds down the steps to the side of the house, under a tree. There in the shade she takes a few short breaths, trying gather herself. She begins to focus on something on the ground in front of her. It's a pair of black boots.  76. Raymond stands a couple yards away watching, not knowing to do. She sees him and the tears spill from her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Oh - Mrs. Whitaker... He takes a step toward her and stops.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Is there - anything I can do? She shakes her head no, wiping the tears and trying to sh her forehead from view.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you, no. I'm fine, really. It's just - been a difficult time. With my husband.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: It does happen. Between married people.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I know it does. I just... (she turns away) It's so embarrassing. Please forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Forgive you for what? He looks off for a moment, then back at Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Mrs. Whitaker, listen. I have to go deliver some shrubs to a farmhouse just out of town. Which means I have to get a move on. why don't you come on along for the ride? Little fresh air, change of scenery? Might help take your mind off things. Cathy feels a sudden guard.  77.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: No. I couldn't. But thank you Raymond. For offering. That's very kind of you.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: (off) Mrs. Whitaker? Are you out here? Cathy turns, calling out toward the porch.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Yes, Sybil!

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: (off) It's Mrs. Barker on the phone!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sybil! I'll be right in! (back to Raymond) I should get back.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Okay. She turns to leave. From Raymond's view beneath the tree can see her legs striding back to the porch and up the st into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy walks over to the table by the window and picks up phone.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Hello?... Yes. How are you, Mrs Barker... Not at all... As Cathy talks she steps over toward her vanity and glanc at herself in the mirror. She adjusts her hair so that it covers her forehead as before.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Yes, I was planning to pick them up at five... I see. So you'd like to switch for Thursday? No, I don't think that would be a problem... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CATHY(cont 'd) Well I'm glad I could be of help... Certainly... Bye now. Cathy steps back to the table and hangs up the phone, sti for a moment. She glances out the window into the yard. Raymond can be seen throwing his toolbag over his shoulde and setting off for the day. Cathy remains looking out, in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond is just shutting the door of his truck when Mrs. Whitaker comes walking briskly from the house. She is wea her coat and her lilac scarf.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Raymond! Raymond turns, sees her coming.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Mrs. Whitaker... Cathy stops a couple of yards from his truck, feeling suddenly rather awkward.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well, wouldn't you know it. I just received a call and suddenly everything's changed. Anyway. I just... She's doesn't even know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: You changed your mind? Cathy smiles, shyly.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: (smiles back) Well good! Raymond opens his door and gets out.  79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the living room window, Sybil catches sight of Raymond helping Cathy into his truck. She stops what she' doing a moment as Raymond's truck takes off down the street, music swirling

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Raymond's truck driving down a road flanked by gol hills. He turns up the drive of an old ranch house, and drives up to the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large, rustic ranch-house sits on a bluff overlooking t late-Autumn vista of faded gold. Raymond's truck is parke front of the house where Raymond stands with the ranch ow signing a receipt. Cathy has begun strolling past the hou toward a clearing in the trees. [Throughout the following exteriors REAR-PROJECTED facsim succor the close-ups, but all ‘natural splendor’ should shimmer with process. ] Raymond shakes hands with the ranch-owner and starts over where Cathy stands, looking out. On the way he breaks off branch from a tree with white bark and round, golden yell leaves which he presents to her.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: It's lovely. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: It's called a Quaking Aspen. Fairly rare in these parts.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (admiring the branch) It's beautiful. (looking out at the vista) And you were right. What a perfectly lovely spot.  80.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Sometimes a little green, some fresh air, just helps put things back on the shelf. ‘Cause it sure can be a disheveling world out there, every now and again.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I'll say it can. Cathy looks over toward a clearing in the grove.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Is that a path?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Looks like it.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh let's have a peek.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Alright. They start off down the path, Cathy leading, music burgeoning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy and Raymond stroll down the gently winding path, re carpeted by the last of autumn while cloaked in an early winter mist. As they stroll they are each aware of the diminished formalities between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come upon a cluster of wildflowers.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: So you say he’s seeing a specialist?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Yes, well... A psychiatrist really. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CATHY(cont 'd) My husband’s been suffering froma great deal of strain, recently. Uncertainty.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I know he’s in good hands - It’s just... what with everything that’s been going on recently, it just - I don’t know - feels at times like there’s no one left in the world I can talk to! Cathy smiles to herself and looks back at him.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (lightly) Except you! Raymond smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Well. Sometimes it's the people outside our world we confide in best.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Why? Just because they're outside?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: And because they may have had experiences similar to ours. Because they care to listen.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: And once you do. Confide. Share those experiences with someone. They're no longer really outside, are they? They've come upon a small wooden bridge under which a per stream passes. They stop for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: It's lovely, isn't it? She kneels down and looks into the stream. Raymond is looking down at her. There's a sadness in his and he squats down beside her, music waking.  82.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: (with great gentleness) Did he cause that? He is looking at the mark on her forehead. Cathy puts her hand over it and stands, silent for a mome

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: He didn't mean to strike me. She looks down at the stream and takes a step away.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: No. Heaven knows we all have our troubles. I'm sure you yourself...

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know. Ever since running into you at the exhibition... Well I just kept wondering what it must be like. Being the only one in a room. Colored, or whatever it was. How that might possibly feel. I'm sure I've never - She stops, glancing out again at the hills. Raymond looks out as well.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose it's something you sort of grow accustomed to. Over time. Don't get me wrong. There is a world - even right here in Hartford - where everybody does indeed look like me. Only trouble is, very few people ever leave that world. I just want what any father wants for his child, the opportunities growing up I never had.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Naturally.  83.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: But I'll tell you something - If you're really interested -

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh I am.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: (has a sudden thought) Are you hungry? Could you eat something?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (brief silence) I suppose I could.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Tell you what. Let me take you to one my favorite spots, not far from here. On good days they got hot food, cold drink, and just about discernible music.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well it's hard to beat that!

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: (smiling) There you go! Cathy smiles back as they start back up the path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against the gray, industrial side of town, gleams the pin and green neon of Ernie's Bar&Grill. We see Raymond's tru just pulling into the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the street at a Car Wash, a young black attendant gives two short honks from a shiny black Edsel and looks around. A woman in a black feathered hat approaches. It's Mona Lauder.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Here I am! Yoo-hoo?  84. The attendant takes her ticket and escorts her to the driver's seat but Mona tarries a moment, catching sight o something across the street. The attendant looks off in t same direction. Outside Ernie's, Raymond is seen helping Cathy out of his truck, taking her arm and escorting her into the club. Mona remains devilishly fixed as she steps into the car a the attendant shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: (handing him a nickel) Thank you... very much, indeed. Mona starts her engine with a contented little smirk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door opens and Cathy and Raymond step into the entry way of the club.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (fixing her hair) Well I'm hardly dressed for a restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: You look fine. The main room at Ernie's is a smoky den of small square tables and black booths, colored mostly by neon overspill Christmas lights. Most notably, everyone in the room is black. As Raymond and Cathy enter everyone in sight turns and lo

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Raymond. Raymond contains a little smile.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Don't worry. It's a very friendly place. Raymond starts in and Cathy follows, reluctantly. A small blues band is just setting up as an old jukebox plays and couple dances.  85. Raymond passes ESTHER, a dolled-up waitress in her late 2 who scowls at him as he stops, glancing around the room f table.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Say there Esther, darling. what? You don't say hello any more?

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: (checking out Cathy) Looks like you’re speakin’ fine for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Oh, you’re just sore ‘cause I haven’t been coming around like I used to.

dialogues.speaker: ESTHER
dialogues.text: Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Now what do you say about bringing us over a couple of drinks. (to Cathy) What would you like?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh. A daiquiri? If they -

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: One daiquiri, and a bourbon on the rocks. Thank you, doll. Esther rolls her eyes and turns. As Raymond escorts Cathy to a table, a GLARING MAN stands from his table just as Raymond is passing.

dialogues.speaker: GLARING MAN
dialogues.text: (to Raymond) What d'you think you're doing, boy? Raymond passes him without looking, continuing with Cathy a corner table below a mirror and helps Cathy into her ch He sits down opposite her. The glaring man stares after a moment, then takes off adamantly toward the bar.  86.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (a little tense) Well I hope you find this very amusing.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: What do you mean? It's a very welcoming place! (spotting someone and nodding) How you doin’ Gus. A middle-aged man at another table (looking fairly soused raises his glass to Raymond, then to Cathy. Cathy smiles back at him.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: See what I mean? Cathy watches as a second couple step up to the dance-flo Meanwhile Esther returns with drinks and menus.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Thank you, Esther. She leaves.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: (raising his glass) Well. Here's to being the only one. Cathy looks at him a moment and then smiles, shaking her head. She toasts his glass and he laughs.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Really. We don't have to stay if you're not comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: No. As long I keep away from Esther, I think I'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Alright, then. The jukebox song has ended and the band kicks into its fi number, a tender “I’1l Be Seeing You.” Raymond turns to watch, smiling.  87. A few men in blue-collar uniforms are sauntering out of a smoke-filled pool-room, beer bottles in hand. They also s to listen to the band, while two more couples head up to floor to dance. Cathy looks over at Raymond, and smiles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Raymond. He turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: For a lovely afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Well thank you, Mrs. Whitaker. I’ve had one as well.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: ‘Mrs. Whitaker.’ Sounds so formal. Would you - She stops.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: (gently) Would I what? Brief silence.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Ask me to dance? Raymond smiles and slowly stands. Cathy does the same and turns, leading as Raymond follows unhurriedly to the dance-floor. The men in blue-collar uniforms watch Raymond pass with contempt in their eyes, before finally turning and filing of the bar. Cathy stops beneath a blossom of rosy light and turns smiling as Raymond joins her. She takes his hand and they begin to dance, tenderly, in the soft glow of Ernie's surrounded by other dancers and other lovers. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow a vase displaying the golden Quaking Aspen bran as Sybil carries it into the living room. Cathy is gather her belongings, getting ready to leave the house.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, doesn't that look lovely. Let's see now, where should we put it...? How about there, Sybil, by the window? Sybil places the vase on a high end-table near the window

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh yes, that's lovely.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: It certainly is.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (checking her purse) Now where is that list you gave me - Though I swore to Janice I wouldn't be late for her recital.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: You can't miss that.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (finding the list) Here it is. (walking over to her coat) You know, Sybil, I've been meaning to ask you...

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Yes, ma’am?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What is the name of that church group you belong to - the one you've mentioned so often...?

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: You mean at Ebenezer? The bible group?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (putting on her coat) Yes, I believe that was it.  89.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Or was it South Green Baptist. During the Fair Drive. The ladies auxiliary?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I didn't realize there was more than one.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. I always seem to be signing up for something.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well I think that's marvelous Sybil. That you even find the time, what with all you do for us. (putting on her scarf) We just have so much up in the attic I've been meaning to go through. I thought you might know of a church or civic group that could benefit from a donation.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Well - certainly, Mrs. Whitaker. If that's what you're looking for. Places in need are never too hard to find.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (opening the door) Well I suppose you're right about that - Cathy stops with a start. A young black couple are standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Yes? May I - help you with something? Sybil looks on suspiciously, observing the couple's conservative attire and officious clipboards.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Is this the Whitaker residence?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Yes.  90.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Are you - (glancing at a clipboard) Mrs. Frank Whitaker?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: (reciting his standard introduction) Good afternoon, ma’am. Allow me to introduce myself. My name's Reginald Carter and this is Martha Livingston and we're members of the Hartford branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. As a charitable organization we rely heavily on the aid of volunteers and membership revenue from the general public. Perhaps you'd be interested in reading over our complimentary brochure which explains more about the N-A-A-C-P, its many achievements and goals for the future.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well - certainly, I'm familiar with your organization - I just... May I ask how you obtained our name and this address?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: You gave it to us ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I did?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: When you signed our petition supporting the funding initiative.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (thinks for a moment, then) Oh. Yes, I do remember signing for that.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Perhaps you'd be interested in reading over our complimentary -  91.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Yes, I would -

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: If you wouldn't mind signing our roster?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Perhaps - Sybil, would you mind signing for this? I'm terribly late at it is. Sybil, who has tried busying herself at the hall table, l up, just as the phone starts to ring.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (starting out the door) Whoever it is I'm gone! Thank you, Sybil - I should be back by five!

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: (stepping to the door) Yes, ma'am. As Cathy scurries off the three look after, music hanging

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy drives down Hawthorne street looking out her window eagerly, music stirring softly. The red-and-green Christmas decorations on the lamp-posts only seem to accentuate the greyness of the neighborhood. Then she spots it. A small storefront with Christmas trees out front reads DEAGAN GARDEN SHOP. She smiles to herself as she continues on, picking up spe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wind whistles through downtown Hartford as Cathy hurrie out of the local Stop-&-Shop carrying groceries. She smil at a WOMAN passing on the street, and hurries on to her c  92. The woman stops and turns, looking back at Cathy as she g Two ladies are passing down the street - the same two lad who stood snickering with Mona and her uncle at the art s One of them spots Cathy and whispers something to the oth Cathy notices, stopping a moment before shutting the trun her car, then rushes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy dashes in the front door of the building where a si is posted. It reads: BALLET RECITAL TODAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the dimly-lit recital room mothers sit in rows of folding chairs watching as a class of 10 and 11-year-old girls perform a routine. Cathy steps into the main room, hushed in attention, and stops to watch. Janice comes running over.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Mother! A ballet instructor turns and shh's them.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (whispering) Hello, dear. Janice embraces her and then turns to face the recital, curling around her mother and keeping hold of her hand.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Did the recital just begin? Janice nods.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: So where are the other little girls from your class?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Over there. A queer fog of music forms as Cathy looks over to the oth side of the room.  93. All the other girls Janice's age are standing with their mothers at the opposite end of the room. The mothers all seem to be looking over at Cathy (or pretending not to) while clutching their daughter's hands pulling them close. And all the little girls are quiet, staring sleepily at their estranged classmate and her silently tainted-mother. Music spills over

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We MOVE IN from a slow distance, angled toward the garage Cathy follows Janice up the porch steps into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door opens and Cathy and Janice enter the house dank with late afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Sybil, we're home! There's no answer. Suddenly Janice goes running into the house and straight up the stairs. The phone starts to rin

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Janice? Janice? Cathy watches her go. The phone continues ringing and Cat sighs, putting down her purse and scarf and starting into kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Sybil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy enters the kitchen, lit only by the late-day sun. T is no sign of Sybil as she goes to answer the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Hello?  94.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (through receiver) Cathy!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: El?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor crouches on the phone, pane shadows lining her fa

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Oh Cathy, thank heavens you're home. I've been trying you all day.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: El, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (through receiver) So you haven't heard. You haven't heard a thing?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: No - About what? Eleanor, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Oh Cathy, there's been talk. Vicious talk.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (through receiver) What do you mean? About what?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: About you!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (through receiver) Oh, for heaven's sake - What now?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Oh, honey, I wish you never even had to know. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELEANOR(cont'd) It's Mona, Cathy, she's - well, she's just been on some kind of rampage, swearing up and down she saw you and a colored man, somewhere out on Franklin, coming out of a truck or some such thing -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (cont'd through receiver) The same colored man, she claims you were talking to at the art show!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: But that's - that's preposterous! I mean yes I've spoken to Mr. Deagan on occasion. But this makes it sound like -

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (through receiver) Cathy, believe me, I've been at my wits end. You have no idea what it's been like around here - the phone's been ringing off the hook since eight this morning!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: But Eleanor - the entire thing - is so absurd!

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (through receiver) Darling, I know.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: But what in the world can I do?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (through receiver) Well. I suppose you could start by getting yourself another gardener. Cathy suddenly turns. Frank is standing in the shadows off the kitchen, looking down.  96.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank! What on earth - I didn't even hear you - (to Eleanor) Eleanor, Frank just walked in. Can I call you back?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (through receiver) Of course. You go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I'll call you later. Cathy hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank, what are you doing home? Is everything alright - ? He starts toward her, out of the dark, a drink in his han

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Just tell me one goddamn thing.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Is it true? What they're saying?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, Frank, I can't believe you even

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Because if it is, even the slightest bit, so help me God, Cathleen -

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank I'm sorry you ever even had to hear of such nonsense!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yea', well, Dick Dawson didn't seem to think it was such nonsense when he snuck away from his desk today to phone me -

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Good heavens -  Silence. 97.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He says the whole friggin' town's been talking!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank, Sybil will hear you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I sent her out. - Christ, Cathleen! Do you even have the slightest idea what this means? Do you realize the kind of effect this could have on me and the reputation I've spent the past eight years of my life trying to build? For you and the children and the company?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank, I swear to you, whatever Mona Lauder saw or thought she saw was entirely a figment of that woman's hateful imagination! Yes. I'd spoken with Raymond Deagan on certain occasions - he brought his little girl to Eleanor's art show! But evidently, even here in Hartford, the idea of a white woman even speaking to a colored man is more than any -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Please! Spare me the Negro rights!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank, you know what that woman is capable of. Besides I - I've already given him notice. We won't be seeing the man again.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Is that why you're home? Because of what Dick said? Frank just looks down at his drink, jiggling the glass.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank?  98. He looks up at her with a little smirk, downs the rest of drink, and walks out of the kitchen toward the bar

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What, Frank. (she follows) Did something happen at work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is at the bar refilling his drink when Cathy approaches. She stops and looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I guess you could call it sort of an early Christmas bonus.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What do mean? Frank takes his drink over to the couches and flops into

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: A month of rest and relaxation'! Can you imagine? During the busiest season of the year?! I mean what a goddamn honor!! But I guess when you consider the bang-up job I've been doing, ever since good ole Dr. Bowman entered the scene! And for being, as Millstein put it - what? - "years overdo'! -

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: But Frank you do deserve a vacation, after all you've given them.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well, Palm Springs is supposed to be nice, says the word from on high.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank, I know it might not seem it now, but with everything that's happened, a trip somewhere, away from it all... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CATHY(cont 'd) Frank, it might just be the best thing in the world. For both of us. He just looks down.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, Frank. What a wretched day it must have been for you, darling - All at once the front door bursts open and David rushes i Cathy stands up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Say! What do you know, pop's home! What're you doing home, pop? Cathy approaches David, gathering up her purse and scarf starting up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Your father has work to do, David. It's best you help yourself to a glass of milk and get started straightaway on your studies.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes, mother. Say, pop -

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Mind your mother, David.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy closes the bedroom door behind her and stops. A low tremor of music rises as the late day sun filters through curtains a peach and purple fume. Cathy walks slowly towa the window and stops, looking out Dusk has cast an early freeze over the Whitaker yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond stands outside his shop in the opaline dusk, show a Christmas tree to a middle-aged man. JAKE, a teenage employee, steps out from inside.  100.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Say, Mr. Deagan!

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Yes, Jake?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: There's a lady on the phone for you.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: I’1l be right there. (to the customer ) Would you excuse me a moment? I’m terribly sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond picks up a wall-phone near the front door, as Christmas colors bleed through the Garden Shop windows be him.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Yes? This is Raymond Deagan. It’s Cathy, and Raymond can’t conceal his pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Oh, hello... That’s right. Is everything - ? (he listens) Yea. I think I could... Alright... I’1l see you tomorrow then. He hangs up the phone but remains a moment, music bridgin

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. KELLER’S DRUG-STORE - DOWNTOWN HARTFORD - DAY Through the large, Christmas-trimmed windows of Keller’s store we see Cathy, wearing sunglasses and scarf, crossin the street. Raymond waits at the corner of the old-fashioned, seasona adorned establishment, moderately busy for the middle of day. The door opens and Cathy walks directly over, stoppi beside him.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Hello.  101.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Hello. (silence) Thank you for meeting me. I realize you have a busy schedule.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Worked out fine. I was glad you called. He turns to her with a smile, but Cathy darts a glance to counter where Two women are glaring and whispering.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: You sure everything's alright? Cathy exhales, closing her eyes. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: What is it? The SODA JERK has been watching them from the other end o the counter.

dialogues.speaker: SODA JERK
dialogues.text: Uh - Is there something I can do for you folks?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (quietly) Can we leave here?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Of course. Raymond quickly escorts Cathy, head ducked into her colla out to the street.

dialogues.speaker: SODA JERK
dialogues.text: Maybe that isn't such a bad idea! Several customers turn and glare as they go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond and Cathy are turning down the first corner.  102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 20's-style movie theater stands across the street streaked in winter light. The marquee reads HILDA CRANE a THE BOLD AND THE BRAVE. Cathy and Raymond cross over to the theater and stop unde its awning. Cathy looks down.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: What is it? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I wanted to see you in person Raymond. I just - I can't - (she stops)

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Can't what?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: It just isn't plausible, Raymond, for me to be friends with you. Raymond tenses.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You've been so very kind. To me. And I've been perfectly reckless and foolish in return... thinking -

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: What? That one person could reach out to another? Take an interest in another? And that maybe, for one fleeting instant, could manage to see beyond the surface - beyond the color of things? Cathy sighs and thinks a moment

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Do you think we ever really do? See beyond those things? The surface of things?  103.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: ‘Just beyond the fall from grace/Behold that ever shining place.’ Yes, I do. I don’t really have a choice.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (softly) I wish I could. She takes his hand, a bit formally.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Good luck to you, Raymond. She starts to turn away to leave when Raymond grabs her a

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Mrs. Whitaker! A passing couple with a stroller turn and stop. Schoolgirls waiting to buy tickets do the same.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (still softly) Raymond - please don't - A TALL MAN in shirt-sleeves and suspenders shouts from ac the street.

dialogues.speaker: TALL MAN
dialogues.text: You! Boy! Hands off! Raymond turns.

dialogues.speaker: TALL MAN
dialogues.text: Yea, you! Cathy puts her hand over Raymond's and gently removes it. takes a step back. Raymond stands helplessly, everyone watching.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh Raymond - He looks at her with such sadness.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (as much to herself) You're so beautiful.  104. She mouths ‘bye’ and turns, starting off briskly down the street. Spectators break into murmurs. The tall man across the street slowly turns and continues his way. Raymond looks back in Cathy's direction as she disappears around the corner. Music booms, sweeping us inexorably forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a brisk winter day and light flurries are just start to sprinkle up the sky. David's junior-football team has broken and he and the others are walking back from the fi Along the sidewalk a row of black school-kids in uniform making their way down the street. One of the children is Sarah Deagan, Raymond's daughter, is walking with another little girl her age.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH'S FRIEND
dialogues.text: Which' is how come I almost fell asleep during Math-class, on account of my brother playin’ his records all night long - until my mama came and made him switch it off. And I don't even like that type of music! Sarah's attention has turned to a powder blue Chevrolet slowing down near the football field. It's Cathy's car, w Sarah recognizes as it comes to a stop. She watches as Da walking back with his friend Hutch, calls out to his moth in the car.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Mother! Can I sleep over at Hutch's tonight? Please!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Not tonight, David. Your father's home and we're having a family dinner.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH'S FRIEND
dialogues.text: Who's that?  105.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Oh, just some friends of my daddy. You don't have to wait, I'll catch up. Sarah's friend continues on as Sarah remains for a moment watching.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You never let me stay over

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Next time, David, I promise. Now please get in the car, I'm late as it is. David climbs into the back-seat - Janice is seated in fro and the car begins to pull out. Sarah smiles as it approaches. But as she lifts her hand wave hello only Janice seems to notice her - whisking pas the window as they go. Sarah watches as the car speeds off down the road. She lo back in the direction of her group, but now her classmate are a good block away. And the snow has begun picking up. she plunges her hands in her pockets and starts up after them. Up ahead where the block narrows, Hutch and two of his friends stand leaning against the fence, sharing a cigare Sarah notices them ahead. Hutch is the first one to spot her, and he stares hard as approaches. A chill of music is felt as Hutch leans over starts whispering to the others. As they look back at her laugh the music picks up a jazzy beat. Sarah approaches, tucking her head down sullenly.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Hey fellas, look who's comin'! It's daddy's girl! Hey there daddy's girl! Where do think you're going?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (a mumble) Home.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Home to see your daddy?... Yea, and his white girl?  106. Suddenly Sarah tears off, running down the street, music turning fast and brassy. The boys exchange brief smiles before grabbing rocks from the ground and taking off afte her.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Hey! Where ya goin’? We just want to play! Sarah looks back as she runs and sees them following. She starts to panic but continues running, dropping her schoolbooks along the way. She comes to a busy intersection and turns off into an al

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah tears around a trash dumpster only to discover that alley doesn't go through. She turns around just as Hutch the others arrive, sealing her off, music simmering. The falls steadily now.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Uh-oh! Wrong turn, daddy's girl!

dialogues.speaker: 2ND BOY
dialogues.text: Hey daddy's girl! Over here! With their stone-wielding arms in the air, the boys begin slowly tightening around her, music building. Sarah begin backstepping toward the wall.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Yep! She made a wrong turn alright! He doubles back with his rock, pitcher style, as the musi explodes into wild rhythm, and the other two follow.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Just like her daddy! All at once their rocks go hurling at Sarah, with Hutch's coming last and hard and hitting her in the head. It knoc her back and she falls to the ground. For a split-second the boys are frozen. Then all at once take off down the street, music reaching a brassy, franti peak. RAPID FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music shimmers suddenly as the top of an unwrapped presen lifted, revealing amid a blossom of tissue a satiny pair new ballet slippers. We ascend.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Oh, it is them, it is! Oh thank you, mother! Thank you, father! Kaleidoscopic light multicolors the rosy, Christmas-strew living room as Janice scurries over to Frank on the couch Cathy returns with an egg nog. David sits on the rug, poo over his new electric train-set. Outside, the backyard glistens with snow.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas, darling!

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Now I'll be as good as all the other girls in class.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (handing him his drink) There you are, darling. Just the way you like it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (holding up one of the cars) Pop! Look at the steam engine!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Wonderful!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well, look at that. (walking over to the fireplace) I knew I was forgetting something! Cathy returns with Frank's Christmas stocking.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: There you are, darling! A little something for Mr. and Mrs. Clause! Frank overturns the stocking and a handful of travel brochures slip out onto the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What 've we got here? Acapulco, Miami, Palm Springs, Bermuda. Cathy sits down beside him on the arm of the couch.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Take your pick, darling. It's your choice.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: This mean you're paying?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well Rio, I know, is a bit extravagant, but the rest are really all quite affordable. As far as warm weather goes. This time of year.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don't know. Stan's always raving about Miami.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, Frank I think Miami would be a dream! El says it's just darling. Everything's pink.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh yea? (tiny pause) Then maybe we oughta consider Bermuda. Cathy looks at him. Frank cracks a little smile. Music sweeps up as Cathy embraces him.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, Frank! I do love you, darling. I do. 108.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music can be heard spilling out from the glittering suppe club, jutting off the side of the modern, palm-lined reso  109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy and Frank dance together on the terrace of the sparkling venue, all decked out for New Year's, under the stars. A small band is playing and several other couples dancing. And though it's not without tension it's clear t are each trying to make the vacation as pleasant as can b

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I must say you look extremely fetching all gussied up in your white tux and tie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well it's a good thing, since I can hardly breath in it.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh it's not that bad. (silence) You like my dress?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes. Very much. Didn't I say?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You did not.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well it's a ravishing dress. And a ravishing girl to go with it.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: That's more like it. The song ends and everyone claps for the band. Frank kiss Cathy tenderly on the lips, under the stars, and she smil into his eyes. Frank puts his arm around her gently and escorts her back to their table. As they near their table they are intercepted by a large family being seated. The handsome middle-aged parents sit down first, followed by five blond, handsome children ranging from late teens to late 20's in age. The BLOND FA addresses Frank and Cathy:

dialogues.speaker: BLOND FATHER
dialogues.text: Excuse us.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No problem at all.  110. One of the middle sons, the prettiest, watches Frank clos as he passes. Cathy doesn't notice. But Frank does.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You have a lovely family.

dialogues.speaker: BLOND FATHER
dialogues.text: Thank you. Happy New Year.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Happy New Year to you. Frank nods to the table, catching another glimpse of the pretty blond boy's stare. And he and Cathy take their sea

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank, do you remember that summer? At your uncle's in Vermont? Janice wasn't even born yet. When David broke his finger on the water pump?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (remembering) Oh yea.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Whatever happened to that house?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Think Margaret eventually put it on the market.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: That was a wonderful old place. All those wonderful barbeques.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It was a good summer - (distracted by the noise)

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: It must be almost time. Cathy lifts her glass and Frank refills it, then refills own. He glances over toward the ruckus from other tables. The blond table is awash in champagne and the pretty son fully absorbed in the festivities. From the bandstand, the M.C. leads the room in a rousing countdown.  111.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: ... Five - four - three - two - one

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy and Frank toast their champagne and kiss through th rain of pale blue confetti and all the shimmering cheer surrounding them.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Happy New Year, darling!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Happy New Year, dear Music swirls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are surveying a pleasing aqua-blue scene of pleasure-g by the pool. A girl with a pink bathing cap swan-dives in the sparkling water, which is littered with swimmers and children frolicking by the steps. Frank is just finishing some laps and stops at the shallo end to catch his breath. He sits down on a step, still ha submerged, and smiles at the mothers of the splashing toddlers. He notices something at the other end of the po A few members of the blond family are just coming out dressed in swimwear and robes. They grab a few lounges an chairs and start to settle. The pretty son doesn't seem t among them. Frank stands, stretches. He steps out of the water and reaches for his towel just as a small black boy, age 4 or goes skipping past him into the first step of the pool. His father, a HOTEL WAITER, is running over from the hut- style snack-bar.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL WAITER
dialogues.text: (calling out) Martin! Martin, get outa there! You know you're not allowed in there! Cathy, who sits among a row of lounges under an umbrella, looks up from her magazine. A woman with a baby is already stepping efficiently out o the pool while others stand, dumbstruck.  112. Everyone else in the water, save one man doing laps, just stares at the tiny intruder. Instantly the waiter arrives yanks his son out of the water.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL WAITER
dialogues.text: (forcefully) Now what did I tell you about going in that pool?! You know you're not allowed in there! He carries his crying boy off. Frank turns toward Cathy and shrugs. He starts back, dryi himself off on the way.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Hello, there.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well hello. Frank plops himself down on the lounge, flat on his back, exhales.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Mmmm. Good swim, darling?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (eyes closed, nodding) Mmm.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Feel good?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Mmm.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Isn't the sun just marvelous? But her expression changes when she glances back toward t pool. Kids who were playing now stare across the pool to the shallow end blankly. The last few bathers near the steps just stepping out of the water, leaving the entire area cleared. A MOTHER in an unbecoming swimsuit calls out to her DAUGH

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Donna?  113.

dialogues.speaker: DAUGHTER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Time to get out.

dialogues.speaker: DAUGHTER
dialogues.text: But why?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (sharply) Because I said so. The daughter starts swimming reluctantly to the edge, jus the man doing laps makes his final pass. We see the girl in the pink swimming cap climbing up the small ladder in the deep end. Within moments the pool is completely empty. Frank and Cathy observe in silence. Before turning back, Frank takes a final glance at the bl family gathering. The pretty son has just arrived, wearing a white terry-cl robe and a beach bag over his shoulder. He doesn't notice Frank. We hear Cathy slap shut her magazine.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well that does it. Frank turns.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I think I've heard quite enough about fashion and advice for one afternoon! I do believe it's time for my Miss Mitchell. Cathy opens up her canvas bag but doesn't see her book.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, heavens.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I must have left it in the room. So silly.  114.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You want me to go?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: No, darling. You just sat down.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don't mind. (he sits up)

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What? No, Frank. I’ll go. Frank stands up and flexes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It’s fine. I want to get a paper anyway.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yea. He grabs his shirt and room-key and starts off toward the room - in the opposite direction of the blond boy by the pool.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you, darling. I’m sure it’s just there on the night-stand. INT. FRANK’S ROOM - DAY Frank has left the door ajar as he gathers his wallet and Cathy’s book. He stops for a second in front of the mirro and regards himself in his wear. Not bad, for a man his a Then suddenly he senses something. A hum of music hangs i the air as he turns his head to the gap in the door. There, standing and staring at Frank, is the blond boy. H holds his robe in one hand, revealing a lithe, white body squeezed into pale orange swim-trunks. Frank stares back, captive. The boy’s fingers are quietly grazing his crotch.  115. Slowly, like a sleepwalker, Frank begins to approach, mus deepening. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: They're here! I see their car! They're here!

dialogues.speaker: FADE UP ON
dialogues.text: Music lightens as David, Janice and Sybil all hurry to th door which flies open on Cathy and Frank, armored with gi and luggage.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Mother! Father!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hi-ya pop! Hey mother!

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Welcome home, Mr. And Mrs. Whitaker.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well look at you all! what a lovely greeting!

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: So mother was it dreamy?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Listen to you! Dreamy!

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: (taking Mr. Whitaker's suitcase) Did you have a nice time Mr. Whitaker?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes, Sybil. It was very relaxing.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Say, pop!  116.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: David, help Sybil with the luggage. Frank sits down on the living room sofa as Sybil starts u the stairs with a suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Pop, you'll never guess what happened at school this week? Try and guess!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I give up.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: David!

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: (lugging a suitcase up the stairs) I'm helping, mother!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Billy Hutchison and these two other boys all got expelled from school!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You mean suspended. Sybil is starting back down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No! Expelled! I swear! For throwing a rock at a girl's head.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: That's terrible. A little girl from school?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No. She was a Negro.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What? Who told you such a thing?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Tommy Hawkings. He saw. So he had to tell the principal. Cathy glances up at Sybil who continues slowly down the stairs.  117.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Sybil? Is this true? Sybil glances over to Frank and back to Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. I'm afraid it is. Cathy looks over at Frank incredulously.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What in heaven's name has gotten into this town?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It's just a couple of foolish kids.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hutch said they were just trying to teach her a lesson. Sybil continues on into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well I think it's dreadful. And you're certainly not to see that Hutch boy again. You understand me?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: While you're there David, how about flipping on the set for your old man.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Sure, pop. Cathy sighs, picking up the mail from the hall table, and starts upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy enters the dark room, flips on the light and puts d her things. She walks over to the small desk by the windo and puts down the mail. There, among the bills, she notices the NAACP brochure. S picks it up.  118. Close on brochure, music taking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy’s finger is scanning the telephone book for a listi and comes to rest on a number for the NAACP Information L Then she lifts the receiver off the phone and starts dial She is sitting at the dining room table, half-toned by a of wintery light, while Janice sits at the coffee table d her homework.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Mother, how do you spell ‘skirt’?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: One minute, dear. Mother’s making a call. (she finishes dialing and waits) Yes - hello. I was wondering if you could help me possibly. I just recently received your brochure - which I found extremely informative - and was curious to learn a little more about what was entailed precisely - in your volunteer program - in terms of particular skills and so on. You see I - what?... Yes, I can hold. Cathy hears the front door opening and turns. Frank is walking in the door wearing a snow-dusted coat a hat, looking beat.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Father’s home!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (complete surprise) Erank? What happened to the match? Tiny smile.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh, my shoulder’s been acting up. I couldn’t sit there any longer.  119.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You didn’t say anything. He starts taking off his coat and mittens by the coat-rac

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Father, I did the splits today. Wanna see?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (hanging up the phone) Janice, your father just walked in the door. And you have schoolwork to finish.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Yes, mother.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You know, Frank. You never had that physical. I certainly think you're due for one, dear. Can I call Dr Ellis? It's been three years Frank. Frank doesn't answer as he walks over to the couch and si down with the TV guide.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You know my brothers had physicals every year on their birthday, all during school. Father insisted. He doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Did I tell you the pediatrician thinks Janice is going to need braces?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Father, do I have to!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Apparently our little girl has an over -bite. David rushes in from the backyard carrying a bucket and r

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Say, pop! You'll never guess what I'm doing?  120.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: David, where is your coat?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: In the garage.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: And what's it doing there?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’m waxin’ pop’s car! It’s gonna look swell, pop.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: David! How many times do I have to tell you children - you are not permitted outdoors in this kind of weather if you're not properly dressed. It’s ten below zero outside, they're expecting flurries! Do you understand me? David?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Because I give up. If you children want to go and catch your death of cold then so be it. I mean you try talking sense to them, Frank because nothing I say ever seems to- All of the sudden Frank bursts into tears.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank! Janice and David are stunned, staring at their father

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank! What's the matter - ! She gets up from her chair and starts over to him, a dark mist of music forming.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh - God! Janice begins to cry.  121.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (urgently) Janice. David. Go upstairs to your rooms. Janice stands, sobbing. David remains, transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Now! Janice runs up the stairs and David follows in a trance. Cathy stands frozen near the foot of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (crying) Oh - Cathy... She approaches him but slowly, with a strange foreboding.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What, Frank. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Something happened...

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What? (nothing) What.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank cries almost like a baby.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’ve fallen in love with someone. Cathy stares.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Who wants to be with me. For a moment, just having said it sobers him some, and he looks back at her. Then he crumbles again.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh Cathy, I think I might have to go! Music deepens as Cathy numbs, staring flatly, unable to m  122.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I just - I never knew... what it was like - I know how cruel that's sounds. But I'm not... - Oh God, Cathy. I tried! I tried so hard to make it go away... I thought I could do it... for you and the children... But I can't! I can't!... He buries his head in his hands. After several seconds she responds.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (lifeless) I assume then... you'll be wanting a divorce? Frank looks up at her, puffy-eyed. But suddenly the tears seem to have stopped. Cathy looks back at him like a stone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (softly) Cathy I’m so sorry. But all at once she turns, and picking up a glass from th table walks straight-headed up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy enters, closes the door and stands frozen, in the d for several seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We look down at Frank who stands alone in the empty livin room. He turns and walks over to the bar and limply pours himself a drink. He stands frozen a moment, drink in hand music gathers, softly. Then he throws it back, walks over his coat and hat and opens the front door of the house. H turns back around for one last look - and closes the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy stands outside her door looking out the landing win She hears the sound of Frank’s car starting off.  123. Filtered through a new snowfall, the red of his brakes ti the dusky sky and rouge her silent profile. Music deepens Cathy walks to the window and stares hard at the telephon She lifts the receiver to her ear. She dials.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (quivery) Eleanor? Eleanor it’s me, Cathy. Music opens as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A soggy snowfall continues as we glide through shiny bran outside the Fine’s house toward the rosy glow of an upsta window. There we see Cathy in the glow of Eleanor's bedro telling her friend the whole story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor reaches for Cathy's hands, music settling.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Oh, Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: So you see, El. You see why I couldn't tell you anything. Anything at all.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Oh you dear, sweet kid. Ina million years I couldn't have imagined. Not Frank! I suppose divorce really is the only option - if only to keep it as far from the children as possible.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I think that's what's been the hardest of all. The endless secrecy. Our entire lives just - shut in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Are there savings?  124.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Nothing much to speak of. And certainly not with Frank's job on the line.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Well honey, you know, if there's anything you need, anything at all -

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, El...

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I mean it. We're here. Alright?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you, El. For always having been. Cathy reflects a moment and stands, walking toward the window.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You know it's funny.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: What's that.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: This whole time, the only person I've been able to talk to. About any of this. (turning back to her) Was Raymond Deagan. Eleanor looks at Cathy in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: It’s true. Well, not in the way Mona intended - Nothing like that! We would just talk! But... Somehow it made me feel - oh, I don’t know. Alive somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances out the window at the rain-dampened snow.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh Eleanor, I know it sounds ridiculous and mad... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CATHY(cont 'd) But I do, I think of him. What he’s doing, what he’s thinking. I do - Cathy turns back to her friend with the wistful smile of girl. Eleanor glances off.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: El? Eleanor gets up and starts tending to the tray of empty c

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: What can I say? You’re so full of surprises. I’m speechless. Cathy looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (little laugh) Though I'm sure I must have looked entirely the fool, crusading away against Mona Lauder and all her so- called inventions-!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Eleanor! - How can you say such a thing?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I didn't say a word! who am I to tell anyone how to lead their lives?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: But El! Nothing happened between us! I told you that!

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Cathy it's none of my business. But you certainly make it sound as if something had. A soft bed of music rises as Cathy looks back at her disarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music continues as Cathy returns home, hanging up her coa and stepping into the dark, silent house. She walks toward the french doors, etched in silver, and stops. There, filtering moonlight through its gilded maze, the branch of Silver-tip spruce still sits in a vase by the window.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: (off) Mrs. Whitaker? Cathy turns toward the kitchen. Sybil stands in the shadows near the kitchen door.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Sybil.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to disturb you ma'am, I just...

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Yes, Sybil?

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: It's something I've been wanting to tell you, ma'am, for some time - Something I believe you'd surely want to know - even if it isn't... exactly my place...

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Sybil, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: It's about the little colored girl, ma'am. The one that got hit?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Yes. What about her?

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, ma'am, but it was Mr Deagan's little girl, Sarah -  127.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What! Oh God, Sybil, it wasn't!

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: The neighbors tell me she's doing just fine -

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh that dear, sweet little girl. (to Sybil, suddenly incensed) How in God's name, Sybil, could you not have told me this? That was weeks ago - !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and marches to the entry hall, Sybil following.
