dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Oh, Mrs. Whitaker, please don't be cross with me! I didn't want to - makes things any worse!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (throwing on her coat) Sybil, Sybil do you have any idea where Mr. Deagan lives?

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: I believe he's been at his father's old place on 12th and Governor.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: 12th and Governor. Thank you Sybil. Cathy grabs her purse and opens the door, rain falling.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: You’re going there now?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Please just keep an eye on the children for me. I won’t be long. (she starts out)

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Mrs. Whitaker!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (turns back, hurriedly) What?  128.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Would you like me to go with you ma’ am?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: No, Sybil. No. I’ll be fine. Thank you. Music billows as Sybil watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain falls upon the inky, lamp-lit night as we loom down slowly upon a small, wood bungalow, the front windows of which appear to have been boarded up. Through the window downstairs we can just glimpse Raymond walking past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond is bringing a freshly made cup of hot chocolate i the living room, stirring as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: And here we have it! Your daddy's super-duper world-renowned hot cocoa specially prepared for his super-duper number one girl! He hands the cup to Sarah who is stretched out on the cou with pillow and blanket watching TV. A small, square band on her forehead still marks her injury.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Thank you, daddy.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: How you feeling, baby?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Fine, daddy.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: What's that you're watching, anyway? There's a knock at the door. Raymond stops.  129.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Who on earth...? He walks to the front.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Yes? The door opens on Cathy, turning suddenly to face him.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Raymond! Oh Raymond I just heard. Just this instant. I heard and I got in my car. (she stops) How are you? How's Sarah?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: We're fine. Thank you. A car passes and Raymond looks out nervously.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: (semi-whisper, gesturing) Meet me around the side. Cathy nods and starts back down the steps as Raymond step back inside the house.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: (grabbing his coat) Sarah, everything's alright, honey. I'll just be outside for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Okay daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy stands facing away, softly illuminated by an outdoo lamp, along the side of Raymond's bungalow. She hears footsteps and turns. Raymond stands near the corner of the house, looking at h

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh Raymond. (taking a few steps closer) What you must have been through. Raymond looks down and shuffles forward some as well.  130.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What's being done, to the boys who-?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Nothing. I won't make her go through it again. Not now. Not with rocks coming through the window every night.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Raymond, that's hateful.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: It's not white's throwing them - it's coloreds.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Oh, yea - Seems to be the one place where whites and coloreds are in full harmony. Anyway, we'll be out of here soon enough, once and for all.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You're moving?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Yea.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Where to?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: I have a... (emptying some flooded trash-lids) brother in Baltimore. Says he can find me work out there. So we're packing up the house. Two weeks Friday we'll be on the 4:30 train, heading South.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: But what about your business, your shop?

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: The business is through. No one's gonna hire me. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAYMOND( cont'd) So I'm selling the shop to a cousin of mine. No... (he looks off) It's pretty well finished for me here. (a thought stops him) I've never lived anywhere but Hartford.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (all vulnerability) Perhaps... sometime in the future... after you're settled - I could... perhaps come for a visit See Baltimore? You see I... Well it looks as if I'm to be single again. Raymond looks at her. It makes him sad. He smiles softly. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Oh, Mrs. Whitaker.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (softly) Please call me Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: (softly) Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: No one would know us there.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: I'm just not sure... it would be such a wise idea. After... well, everything that’s - Cathy looks at him, feeling the first chill of an impendi loss.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: All that matters now - what’s got to matter most - is what’s right for Sarah. I’ve learned my lesson about mixing with other worlds. And I’ve seen the sparks fly... (tenderly) All kinds. Cathy turns away, hiding sudden tears.  132. Raymond puts a hand on her shoulder, which she covers wit hers.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Have a proud life. A splendid life. Will you do that? She closes her eyes. He kisses her fingertips.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Goodbye Cathy. His fingers slip from hers. She stands a moment, the black, liquid sky continuing its downpour, then starts walking, hurriedly, to her car. She doesn’t look back. Raymond watches gravely, then turns and starts slowly bac inside. To which a rising music as bottomless as the sea suddenly answers, spilling over and engulfing what follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The curtains are drawn and Cathy lays across the shadowy surface of her bed, sobbing. Everything she's kept inside seems to spill from her now, as we move in gently through aquanautic shadows. Music fades, leaving us alone with her sounds - when the phone starts ringing. Cathy stops, listening. Then sits u bed and looks over at it, wiping her eyes. Then she slips the edge of the bed and walks over to the writing table t answer it. Outside, the rain appears to have stopped.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (through receiver) Cathy? Did I wake you?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Frank?  133.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sits on the phone against blue floss hotel wallpape his face in shadow.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m sorry to call this late. I hope I didn’t...

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: No. I was awake.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (through receiver) I didn’t want to - upset the children.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: No. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (through receiver) How are they, by the way?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Fine. Just fine. They still ask when you'll be coming home.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I know. I know. I guess that's - partly why I was calling... Frank sits hunched-over a little table in the dark. Behin him, spread out in bed with newspapers and a half-eaten b of chocolates, the pretty blond boy watches a large Tv.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I, uh - I got a call from Dick yesterday. Said everything was... set, papers drawn up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy just listens. Expressionless.  134.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (through receiver) He wanted to know... how Thursday was for you. Three o'clock sometime. I told him I thought you might have carpool Thursdays but I wasn't absolutely certain. So I said I would check.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (distantly) You never could remember my carpool days. And they've always been the same, Wednesdays and Fridays, as long as I can remember.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (through receiver) Wednesdays and Fridays. Of course. Same old absent-minded -

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: What time... did you say on Thursday?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (through receiver) What?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: The appointment? What time?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (through receiver) Oh - Three. Three o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (brief silence) Alright.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (through receiver) Okay. Well... Great. That was it really. I know it's late.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (through receiver) So I guess I'll see you on - Thursday, then.  135.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: See you Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music rises like a steam.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Frank. She hangs up the phone and sits very still for several seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, through the bedroom window, we can see the new gardener - an Asian man - watering the plants. We slowly inside to find Cathy sitting at her bedroom table finishi up the bills.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (writing) Sixty-seven dollars and thirty-two cents. (looking up a moment) Now what is today...? She glances over at her desk-calendar, turning the page t the proper day. It reads: SATURDAY, MARCH 1. She copies the date down in her checkbook, then stops a moment. She looks back at the calendar as if trying to remember something. Snapping back to business, she tears the check, places it in an envelope and seals it. She gat up her other mail and stands, glancing once around the ro before grabbing her purse and sunglasses and starting out door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soft sunlight shimmers through windows as Cathy comes down the stairs.  136. Sybil is busy polishing the dining room table.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, Sybil. You don’t need to be doing that.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: It’s Friday.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I know it is, but... There’s just so much more to do now. I can hardly expect you to be polishing the table every week.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: No reason not to keep things up Mrs. Whitaker. No reason at all.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I know. Cathy stops in front of the mirror to fix her hair and pu her sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: Don't forget the grocery list.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Oh! Thank you, Sybil - (she starts checking her pockets) I don't know how in the world I'd ever manage - Here it is. She takes out the shopping list but finds something else the pocket. She pulls out a scarf - the lilac scarf - forgotten there since her afternoon with Raymond. Music whispers. She looks at it a moment, then up at the mirror where it' reflected in her hand. She puts it on over her hair and glasses and stops a moment, looking at herself.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I shouldn't be long, Sybil.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL
dialogues.text: (still bent over, polishing) Alright, Mrs. Whitaker.  137. Cathy turns, music rising, and starts out the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy drives up in front of the large green field, stuffe with boys in red, sauntering back to the bleachers. David amongst them, walking arm-in-arm with another boy, when h spots his mother’s car and waves.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Say - Mother!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Go and gather your things, David. Mother’s in a hurry! David races his friends to the bench where he grabs his knapsack and goes running to the car. He hops in the fron and we ascend as Cathy takes off down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy is walking Janice, dressed for ballet, out the door her dance-school.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: See you next week! The door shuts behind them as Cathy hurries Janice into t car. She rushes around to the driver's side, hops inside car, and is off again, zipping down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A soft, new sun warms the brick of the Hartford Train Station, standing proudly in the center of town. We see Cathy's car just pulling up and turning into the parking section.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Say! Why are we turning in here?  138. Cathy is pulling into a parking space.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Mother just needs to dash inside for two shakes while you and your sister wait inside in the car.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No fair!

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: (getting out of the car) I'll be right back. Now stay put. Both of you. And lock the door. Cathy shuts the door of the car and looks up at the clock outside. It reads: 4:24. She hurries on inside. [Music continues in some form through to the end of the f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy emerges out of the stairway onto the platform, a ju of boarding and goodbyes. She looks back and forth anxiou then starts walking down the platform toward the front of train. She hurries along, looking every-which-way, past all the others. Then suddenly she stops. Raymond stands on the platform, gingerly helping Sarah up steps of the train while a black attendant loads their luggage into an open compartment. Cathy starts over to them, but Raymond slips inside the t without seeing her. Cathy just stares at the door, watching others continue inside. Right in front of her A heavy-set Italian man is saying goodbye to his wife and sons. The wife is crying.  139. A CONDUCTOR is passing.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: All aboard! Southbound train to New York and Washington now departing. All aboard! Cathy looks back at the train door just as Raymond reappears, stepping out of the train and addressi the young attendant, who hands him his baggage slip. Cathy takes a few unconscious steps in his direction. Raymond tips the attendant and shakes his hand and starts back to the door of the train. He takes one step up and stops, turning around again.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: All aboard! All aboard! He sees her. She smiles for being seen. Raymond smiles warmly back. And suddenly - cruelly - the train begins to move. Though one luxurious moment it actually sweeps them together - w Raymond gliding toward Cathy and then crossing her - befo setting off on its inexorable pull. Cathy lifts a tiny hand goodbye. Raymond lifts his in return. She smiles, tears starting, as Raymond continues shrinkin from view before vanishing entirely with the snaking engi Suddenly everything is still. Cathy stands for several seconds, alone in the sudden stillness. Then all at once she turns and begins walking away, down platform. Music resumes with sad resolution.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: That was the day I stopped believing in the wild ardor of things. Perhaps in love, as well. That kind of love.  140.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a great height we see Cathy walking decisively out o the station on her way back to her car, late afternoon su burning orange upon the town.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The love in books and films. The love that tells us to abandon our lives and plans, all for one brief touch of Venus. Cathy climbs into her car, shuts the door and begins driv out of the lot.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So often we fail in that kind of love. The world just seems too fragile a place for it. Or perhaps it's only we who are too fragile. Finally Cathy is turning onto the main road, amid all the other cars heading home. Her powder-blue Chevrolet is engulfed. All around, trees are starting to bloom. Spring has arriv
